revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2018}}
'''Essential Biodiversity Variables''' (EBVs) is a putative set of parameters intended to be the minimum set of broadly agreed upon necessary and sufficient [[biodiversity]] variables for at least national to global monitoring, researching, and forecasting of biodiversity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://geobon.org/essential-biodiversity-variables/what-are-ebvs/|title=What are EBVs?|date=2015-01-26|work=GEO BON|access-date=2017-12-14|language=en-GB}}</ref> They are being developed by an interdisciplinary group of governmental and academic research partners. The initiative aims for a harmonised global biodiversity monitoring system. EBVs would be used to inform biodiversity change indicators, such as the CBD Biodiversity Indicators for the Aichi Targets.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbd.int/sp/targets/|title=Aichi Biodiversity Targets|website=www.cbd.int|language=en|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref>
The concept is partly based on the earlier [[Essential Climate Variables]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://public.wmo.int/en/programmes/global-climate-observing-system/essential-climate-variables|title=Essential Climate Variables|date=2017-06-27|work=World Meteorological Organization|access-date=2017-12-14|language=en}}</ref> It can be generalised as the minimum set of variables for describing and predicting a system's state and dynamics. Areas with more developed EV lists include climate, ocean, and biodiversity.<ref name=":5" />
== EBV Classes / Categories == The current candidate EBVs occupy six classes of Essential Biodiversity Variable: genetic composition, species populations, species traits, community composition, ecosystem structure, and ecosystem function.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://geobon.org/essential-biodiversity-variables/classes/|title=EBV classes|date=2015-02-15|work=GEO BON|access-date=2017-12-19|language=en-GB}}</ref> Within each class are a few to several variables.
{| class="wikitable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" |+ !EBV Class !EBV !Notes |- | rowspan="4" |Genetic composition |Co-ancestry | |- |Allelic diversity | |- |Population genetic differentiation | |- |Breed and variety diversity | |- | rowspan="3" |Species populations |Species distribution |Addressed in.<ref name=":3" /> Track from space.<ref name=":8" /> |- |Population abundance |Addressed in.<ref name=":3" /> |- |Population age / size structure | |- | rowspan="6" |Species traits (subject of <ref name=":6" />) |Phenology |Track from space.<ref name=":8" /> GlobDiversity RS-enabled EBV (land surface phenology).<ref name=":7" /> |- |Body mass |Vegetation height—track from space.<ref name=":8" /> |- |Natal dispersal distance | |- |Migratory behaviour | |- |Demographic traits | |- |Physiological traits |Track from space.<ref name=":8" /> GlobDiversity RS-enabled EBV (canopy chlorophyll concentration).<ref name=":7" /> |- | rowspan="2" |Community composition |Taxonomic diversity | |- |Species interactions | |- | rowspan="4" |Ecosystem function |Net primary production |Track from space.<ref name=":8" /> |- |Secondary production | |- |Nutrient retention | |- |Disturbance regime |Track from space.<ref name=":8" /> Should not be a candidate EBV, due to being non-biological in nature.<ref name=":1" /> |- | rowspan="3" |Ecosystem structure |Habitat structure | |- |Ecosystem extent and fragmentation |Track from space.<ref name=":8" /> GlobDiversity RS-enabled EBV (fragmentation).<ref name=":7" /> |- |Ecosystem composition by functional type | |}
== Associated projects and organisations == As of 2017, participants in the project consist of the GlobDiversity project (funded by the [[European Space Agency]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globdiversity.net/the-globdiversity-project/|title=The GlobDiversity Project}}</ref> under GEO BON (Group on Earth Observations Biodiversity Observation Network; a cooperative project of international universities),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://geobon.org/about/vision-goals/|title=Group on earth Observations}}</ref> and the GLOBIS-B project (Global Infrastructures for Supporting Biodiversity Research; funded by the [[Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development#Horizon 2020|EU Horizon 2020 programme]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globis-b.eu/|title=GLOBIS-B}}</ref>
== Development == The concept was first proposed in 2012<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://old.esaconferencebureau.com/docs/default-source/12m24doc/ebv-workshop-tor-.pdf?sfvrsn=2|title=Frascati Workshop Essential Biodiversity Variables Term of Reference|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gfg2.eu/sites/gfg2.eu/files/Report%20EBV%20meeting%20Frascati.pdf|title=Report EBV Meeting Frascati 26-29 February 2012|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and developed in the following years.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pereira|first=H. M.|last2=Ferrier|first2=S.|last3=Walters|first3=M.|last4=Geller|first4=G. N.|last5=Jongman|first5=R. H. G.|last6=Scholes|first6=R. J.|last7=Bruford|first7=M. W.|last8=Brummitt|first8=N.|last9=Butchart|first9=S. H. M.|date=2013-01-18|title=Essential Biodiversity Variables|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/339/6117/277|journal=Science|language=en|volume=339|issue=6117|pages=277–278|doi=10.1126/science.1229931|issn=0036-8075|pmid=23329036}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Antonio|first=Bombelli,|last2=Ivette|first2=Serral,|date=2015|title=D2.2. EVs current status in different communities and way to move forward|url=https://ddd.uab.cat/record/146882?ln=en|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Skidmore|first=Andrew K.|last2=Pettorelli|first2=Nathalie|last3=Coops|first3=Nicholas C.|last4=Geller|first4=Gary N.|last5=Hansen|first5=Matthew|last6=Lucas|first6=Richard|last7=Mücher|first7=Caspar A.|last8=O'Connor|first8=Brian|last9=Paganini|first9=Marc|date=2015-07-23|title=Environmental science: Agree on biodiversity metrics to track from space|url=http://www.nature.com/news/environmental-science-agree-on-biodiversity-metrics-to-track-from-space-1.18009|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=523|issue=7561|pages=403–405|doi=10.1038/523403a}}</ref>
The GLOBIS-B global cooperation project, aimed to advance the challenge of practical implementation of EBVs by supporting interoperability and cooperation activities among diverse biodiversity infrastructures, started in 2015.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kissling|first=W. Daniel|last2=Hardisty|first2=Alex|last3=García|first3=Enrique Alonso|last4=Santamaria|first4=Monica|last5=Leo|first5=Francesca De|last6=Pesole|first6=Graziano|last7=Freyhof|first7=Jörg|last8=Manset|first8=David|last9=Wissel|first9=Silvia|date=2015-07-03|title=Towards global interoperability for supporting biodiversity research on essential biodiversity variables (EBVs)|url=https://doi.org/10.1080/14888386.2015.1068709|journal=Biodiversity|volume=16|issue=2-3|pages=99–107|doi=10.1080/14888386.2015.1068709|issn=1488-8386}}</ref> The GlobDiversity project of GEO BON, led by the [[University of Zurich]], started in 2017, focusing on specification and engineering of three RS-enabled EBVs.<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=http://geobon.org/the-globdiversity-project-has-started/|title=The GlobDiversity project has started|date=2017-11-01|work=GEO BON|access-date=2017-12-14|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://geobon.org/Downloads/Other_documents/Essential_Biodiversity_Variable_Strategy_v2.pdf|title=GEO BON Strategy for Development of EBVs}}</ref>
The scope and screening of potential variables is under ongoing discussion.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Schmeller|first=Dirk S.|last2=Mihoub|first2=Jean-Baptiste|last3=Bowser|first3=Anne|last4=Arvanitidis|first4=Christos|last5=Costello|first5=Mark J.|last6=Fernandez|first6=Miguel|last7=Geller|first7=Gary N.|last8=Hobern|first8=Donald|last9=Kissling|first9=W. Daniel|date=2017-11-01|title=An operational definition of essential biodiversity variables|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10531-017-1386-9|journal=Biodiversity and Conservation|language=en|volume=26|issue=12|pages=2967–2972|doi=10.1007/s10531-017-1386-9|issn=0960-3115}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globis-b.eu/news/11/globis-b_contributes_to_a_better_definition_of_ebvs.html|title=GLOBIS-B contributes to a better definition of EBVs GLOBIS-B|website=www.globis-b.eu|language=nl|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|date=2017-09-01|title=Taking stock of nature: Essential biodiversity variables explained|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0006320716303652|journal=Biological Conservation|volume=213|pages=252–255|doi=10.1016/j.biocon.2016.09.006|issn=0006-3207}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://www.globis-b.eu/news/10/globis-b_essential_biodiversity_variables_workshop_on_species_traits_held_in_amsterdam.html|title=GLOBIS-B Essential Biodiversity Variables Workshop on Species Traits held in Amsterdam GLOBIS-B|website=www.globis-b.eu|language=nl|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-09-01|title=Essential Biodiversity Variables for measuring change in global freshwater biodiversity|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0006320716303640|journal=Biological Conservation|volume=213|pages=272–279|doi=10.1016/j.biocon.2016.09.005|issn=0006-3207}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-04-01|title=How Essential Biodiversity Variables and remote sensing can help national biodiversity monitoring|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2351989416301482|journal=Global Ecology and Conservation|volume=10|pages=43–59|doi=10.1016/j.gecco.2017.01.007|issn=2351-9894}}</ref>
This includes definition of the species distribution EBV and population abundance EBV, operationalisation of the EBV framework, data and tools for building EBV data products, workflow for building EBV data products, metadata and data sharing standards;<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Kissling|first=W. Daniel|last2=Ahumada|first2=Jorge A.|last3=Bowser|first3=Anne|last4=Fernandez|first4=Miguel|last5=Fernández|first5=Néstor|last6=García|first6=Enrique Alonso|last7=Guralnick|first7=Robert P.|last8=Isaac|first8=Nick J. B.|last9=Kelling|first9=Steve|title=Building essential biodiversity variables (EBVs) of species distribution and abundance at a global scale|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/brv.12359/abstract|journal=Biological Reviews|language=en|pages=n/a–n/a|doi=10.1111/brv.12359|issn=1469-185X}}</ref> and possible integration of abiotic variables (e.g. those emphasised in the Ecosystem Integrity framework) with biotic variables (emphasised in the EBV framework) to achieve comprehensive ecosystem monitoring.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2018-02-01|title=The next generation of site-based long-term ecological monitoring: Linking essential biodiversity variables and ecosystem integrity|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0048969717321095|journal=Science of the Total Environment|volume=613-614|pages=1376–1384|doi=10.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.08.111|issn=0048-9697}}</ref>
"EBV data products" refers to the end product in the EBV information supply chain, from raw observations, to EBV-usable data, to EBV-ready data, to EBV data products. Each of these three types of EBV datasets could be used to produce indicators.<ref name=":3" /> Data sources for EBVs are categorised into four types: extensive and intensive monitoring schemes, ecological field studies, and remote sensing.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-09-01|title=Global biodiversity monitoring: From data sources to Essential Biodiversity Variables|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0006320716302786|journal=Biological Conservation|volume=213|pages=256–263|doi=10.1016/j.biocon.2016.07.014|issn=0006-3207}}</ref> Each have their own often complementary properties, implying that data integration will be important for creation of representative EBVs, as well as identifying and filling data gaps.
== References == <references />
[[Category:Biodiversity]] [[Category:International scientific organizations]]

revision.comment: /* Biology and ecology */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], replaced: is know → is known using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Taxobox | name = Gallagher's free-tailed bat | status = DD | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref=<ref name="iucn 2008">{{cite journal| last1=Mickleburgh| first1= S.| last2= Hutson| first2= A.M.| last3= Bergmans| first3= W.| last4=Cotterill| first4= F.P.D.| year= 2008| title= Chaerephon gallagheri| journal= The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species| volume= 2008| page= e.T4311A10776864| url= https://dx.doi.org/10.2305/IUCN.UK.2008.RLTS.T4311A10776864.en| doi= 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2008.RLTS.T4311A10776864.en}}</ref> | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordata]] | classis = [[Mammal]]ia | ordo = [[Chiroptera]] | familia = [[Molossidae]] | genus = [[Chaerephon (bat)|Chaerephon]] | species = '''''C. gallagheri''''' | binomial = ''Chaerephon gallagheri'' | binomial_authority = (Harrison, 1975) | range_map=Chaerephon gallagheri distribution.svg | synonyms={{species list | Tadarida gallagheri| Harrison, 1975}} }} '''Gallagher's free-tailed bat''' (''Chaerephon gallagheri'') is a [[free-tailed bat]] endemic to the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]. Only one individual has ever been documented.
==Taxonomy and etymology== It was [[species description|described]] as a new species in 1975 by David Harrison. The [[eponym]] for the [[specific epithet (zoology)|species name]] "''gallagheri''" was Major Michael D. Gallagher, who collected the [[holotype]].<ref name="Harrison 1975">{{cite journal|doi=10.1515/mamm.1975.39.2.313|title=A New Species of African Free-Tailed Bat (Chiroptera : Molossidae) Obtained by the Zaire River Expedition|journal=Mammalia|volume=39|issue=2|year=1975|last1=Harrison|first1=David L}}</ref> Its distinct [[morphology (biology)|morphology]] has called into question whether it represents its own genus of bat.<ref name="Kingdon 2013">{{cite book| last1=Kingdon| first1= J.| last2= Happold| first2= D.| last3= Butynski| first3= T.| last4= Hoffmann| first4= M.| last5= Happold| first5= M.| last6= Kalina| first6= J.| date= 2013| title= Mammals of Africa| volume=4| publisher= A&C Black| page=513|isbn=9781408189962|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/250612228_Tadarida_gallagheri_Gallagher%27s_Free-tailed_Bat}}</ref>
==Description== [[File:Chaerephon johorensis.jpg|thumb|left|The interaural membrane in the [[northern free-tailed bat]] (dorsal view)]] [[File:Chaerephon chapini.jpg|thumb|left|Male [[Chapin's free-tailed bat]] displaying its interaural crest]] Its fur is [[umber]] in color, with the belly paler than its back. The fur is short, with individual hairs only {{convert|5-6|mm|in|abbr=on}} long. Its [[patagium|flight membranes]] are grayish-black.<ref name="Kingdon 2013"/> It is a small [[free-tailed bat]], with a forearm length of {{convert|37.5|mm|in|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Harrison 1975"/> Its total length is {{convert|77|mm|in|abbr=on}}; its ear length is {{convert|19|mm|in|abbr=on}}; its tail is {{convert|28|mm|in|abbr=on}} long; its hind foot is {{convert|8.4|mm|in|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="Kingdon 2013"/> Its greatest length of skull is {{convert|16.0|mm|in|abbr=on}}. Its ears are large and conjoined via the interaural membrane.<ref name="Harrison 1975"/> The interaural membrane has a deep, backwards-facing pocket containing an interaural crest with hairs approximately {{convert|9|mm|in|abbr=on}} in length. The bat is likely able to evert this pocket to display the crest.<ref name="Kingdon 2013"/> It is unique in its family due to the presence of large, paired "nasal inflations" similar to those found in the [[mouse-tailed bat]]s.<ref name="Harrison 1975"/> Like other free-tailed bats, its tail extends beyond the margin of the [[interfemoral membrane|uropatagium]]. It has a blunt [[snout]]. Its wings are long and narrow.<ref name="Kingdon 2013"/>
==Biology and ecology== As only one individual—a male—has been documented, little is known about its biology and ecology. Based on other members of its genus, it is hypothesized that Gallagher's free-tailed bat forages for insects at relatively high altitudes with a fast but not maneuverable flight.<ref name="iucn 2008"/><ref name="Kingdon 2013"/>
==Range and habitat== The holotype was collected in the Scierie Forest, approximately {{convert|30|km|mi|abbr=on}} southwest of [[Kindu|Kindu, Democratic Republic of the Congo]].<ref name="Harrison 1975"/> It was captured in a [[mist net]] that was placed in the evergreen undergrowth of a partly-[[deciduous]] forest. The forest where the holotype was collected has been heavily logged.<ref name="Kingdon 2013"/> It is nocturnal, possibly roosting in hollow trees, rock crevices, or caves during the day.<ref name="iucn 2008"/>
==Conservation== It is currently evaluated as [[data deficient]] by the [[IUCN]], meaning that not enough information is available to assess its conservation needs. From 1996–2008, it was considered [[critically endangered]], the most dire assessment category. This species is known from only one individual ever documented—the holotype. Threats to this species are unclear, but possibly include [[habitat destruction]].<ref name="iucn 2008"/>
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{Molossidae}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q1829881}}
[[Category:Chaerephon (bat)]] [[Category:Bats of Africa]] [[Category:Mammals of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Endemic fauna of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Mammals described in 1975]] [[Category:EDGE species]]

revision.comment: Adding local [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "The science of measuring the pressure and temperature history of a metamorphic or intrusive igneous rocks" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|The science of measuring the pressure and temperature history of a metamorphic or intrusive igneous rocks}} '''Geothermobarometry''' is the science of measuring the previous pressure and temperature history of a [[Metamorphic rock|metamorphic]] or intrusive [[igneous]] rocks. Geothermobarometry is a combination of ''geobarometry'', where a pressure of mineral formation is resolved, and ''geothermometry'' where a temperature of formation is resolved.
==Methodology== Geothermobarometry relies upon understanding the temperature and pressure of the formation of minerals within metamorphic and igneous rocks, and is particularly useful in metamorphic rocks. There are several methods of measuring the temperature or pressure of mineral formation relying on chemical [[Chemical equilibrium|equilibrium]] between metamorphic minerals or by measuring the chemical composition of individual minerals.
Thermobarometry relies upon the fact that mineral pairs/assemblages vary their compositions as a function of temperature and pressure. There are numerous extra factors to consider such as oxygen [[fugacity]] and water activity (roughly, the same as concentration). The distribution of component elements between the mineral assemblages is then analysed using an [[electron microprobe]] or [[scanning electron microscope]] (SEM).
Data on the geothermometers and geobarometers is derived from both laboratory studies on artificial mineral assemblages, where minerals are grown at known temperatures and pressures and the chemical equilibrium measured directly, and from calibration using natural systems.
For example, one of the best known and most widely applicable geothermometers is the garnet-biotite relationship where the relative proportions of Fe and Mg in garnet and biotite change with increasing temperature, so measurement of the compositions of these minerals to give the Fe-Mg distribution between them allows the temperature of crystallization to be calculated, given some assumptions.
===Assumptions=== In natural systems, the chemical reactions occur in open systems with unknown geological and chemical histories, and application of geothermobarometers relies on several assumptions that must hold in order for the laboratory data and natural compositions to relate in a valid fashion:
* That the full mineralogical assemblage required for the thermobarometer is present. If not all of the minerals of the reaction are present, or did not equilibrate with each other simultaneously, then any pressures and temperatures calculated for the ideal reaction will deviate from those actually experienced by the rock. * That chemical equilibrium was achieved to a satisfactory degree. This could be impossible to demonstrate definitively, if the minerals of the thermobarometer assemblage are not all observed in contact with each other. * That any minerals in a two-mineral barometer or thermometer grew in equilibrium, which is assumed when the minerals are seen to be in contact. * That the mineral assemblage has not been altered by retrograde metamorphism, which can be assessed using an optical microscope in most cases. * That certain mineralogical assemblages are present. Without these, the accuracy of a reading may be altered from an ideal, and there may be more error inherent in the measurement.
==Techniques== Some techniques include:
===Geothermometers=== * Ti saturation content of [[biotite]] mica.<ref>http://www.geol.lsu.edu/henry/Research/biotite/TiInBiotiteGeothermometer.htm Ti-in biotite geothermometer, Henry et al. 2005</ref> * Fe-Mg exchange between [[garnet]]-biotite and garnet-[[amphibole]]. * Mg-Fe systematics in pigeonites and augites <ref>Lindsley & Andersen 1983 - A Two-pyroxene Thermometer; Journal of Geophysical Research, vol. 88</ref> * Zr content of [[rutile]], effective for higher temperatures than the Ti-in-biotite thermometer. Requires quartz, rutile, and [[zircon]] to be equilibrated.<ref>http://www.rpi.edu/~watsoe/research/Watson_etal_CMP06.pdf Crystallization thermometers for zircon and rutile, Watson et al. 2006; Contributions to mineralogy and petrology v. 151</ref> * [[Titanium in zircon geothermometer |Ti-in-zircon]] crystallization thermometer Note that the Fe-Mg exchange thermometers are empirical (laboratory tested and calibrated) as well as calculated based on a theoretical thermodynamic understanding of the components and phases involved. The Ti-in-biotite thermometer is solely empirical and not well understood thermodynamically.
===Geobarometers=== * GASP; an acronym for the assemblage garnet-(Al<sub>2</sub>SiO<sub>5</sub>)-silica([[quartz]])-[[plagioclase]] * GPMB; an acronym for the assemblage garnet-plagioclase-[[muscovite]]-biotite * Garnet-Plagioclase-Hornblende-Quartz.<ref>Kohn, M.J. and Spear, F.S. (1989): Am. Min. 74:77-84. (Pargasite component)</ref><ref>Kohn, M.J. and Spear, F.S. (1990): Am. Min. 75:89-96. (Tschermakite component)</ref> * Hornblende <ref>Hammerstrom, J.M. and Zen, E.-an. (1986): Am. Min. 71:1297-1313.</ref><ref>Hollister, L.S., Grissom, G.C., Peters, E.K., Stowell, H.H. and Sisson, V.B.(1987): Am. Mineral. 72:231-239.</ref><ref>Johnson, and Rutherford (1989): Geology 17: 837-841.</ref>
Various mineral assemblages rely more upon pressure than temperature; for example reactions which involve a large volume change. At high pressure, specific minerals assume lower volumes (therefore density increases, as the mass does not change) - it is these minerals which are good indicators of paleo-pressure.
===Clinopyroxene thermobarometry=== {{main|Clinopyroxene thermobarometry}}
==References== {{Reflist}} * Winter, D.John.Thermodynamics of metamorphic reactions: Geothermobarometry, 543-556 * Henry, D. J., Guidotti, C. V. and Thomson, J. A. (2005) The Ti-saturation surface for low-to-medium pressure metapelitic biotite: Implications for Geothermometry and Ti-substitution Mechanisms. American Mineralogist, 90, 316-328. * Guidotti, C. V., Cheney, J. T. and Henry, D. J. (1988) Compositional variation of biotite as a function of metamorphic reactions and mineral assemblage in the pelitic schists of western Maine: American Journal of Science-Wones Memorial Volume, v. 288A, 270-292.
[[Category:Metamorphic petrology]] [[Category:Igneous petrology]] [[Category:Scientific modeling]]

revision.comment: rewrite, reflecting what the citations say
clean up, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: the USA → the US
revision.text:
{{good article}} [[File:Charles R. Knight.jpg|thumb|upright=1.7|The artist [[Charles R. Knight]] working on a ''[[Stegosaurus]]'' model, 1899]] <!--[[File:Draak Den Bosch.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Golden [[dragon]] monument, [['s-Hertogenbosch]], The Netherlands]]-->
'''Human uses of reptiles''' have for centuries included both symbolic and practical interactions.
Symbolic uses of [[reptile]]s include accounts in [[mythology]], [[religion]], and [[folklore]] as well as pictorial symbols such as [[medicine]]'s serpent-entwined [[caduceus]]. Myths of creatures with snake-like or reptilian attributes are found around the world, from Chinese and European [[dragon]]s to the Woolunga of Australia. Classical myths told of the nine-headed [[Lernaean Hydra]], the [[Gorgon]] sisters including the snake-haired [[Medusa]], and the snake-legged [[Titan (mythology)|Titans]]. [[Crocodile]]s appear in the religions of [[Ancient Egypt]], in [[Hinduism]], and in [[Aztec]] and other Latin American cultures.
Practical uses of reptiles include the manufacture of snake [[antivenom]] and the farming of crocodiles, principally for [[leather]] but also for meat. Reptiles still pose a threat to human populations, as [[snakebite|snakes kill]] some tens of thousands each year, while [[crocodile attack|crocodiles attack]] and kill hundreds of people per year in Southeast Asia and Africa. However, people keep some reptiles such as [[iguana]]s, [[turtle]]s, and the docile [[corn snake]] as pets.
Soon after their discovery in the nineteenth century, [[Cultural depictions of dinosaurs|dinosaurs were represented]] to the public as the large-scale sculptures of the [[Crystal Palace Dinosaurs]], while in the twentieth century they became important elements in the popular imagination, thought of as maladapted and obsolete failures, but also as fantastic and terrifying creatures in [[monster movie]]s. In folklore, [[crocodile tears|crocodiles were thought to weep]] to lure their prey, or in sorrow for their prey, a tale told in the [[classical era]], and repeated by Sir [[John Mandeville]] and [[William Shakespeare]]. Negative attitudes to reptiles, especially snakes, have led to widespread persecution, contributing to the challenge of conserving reptiles in the face of the effects of human activity such as habitat loss and pollution.
==Context== {{further|Culture|Ethnoherpetology}}
[[Culture]] consists of the [[social behaviour]] and [[Norm (social)|norms]] found in [[human]] [[society|societies]] and transmitted through social [[learning]]. [[Cultural universals]] in all human societies include expressive forms like [[art]], [[music]], [[dance]], [[ritual]], [[religion]], and [[technology|technologies]] like [[tool|tool usage]], [[cooking]], [[shelter (building)|shelter]], and [[clothing]]. The concept of [[material culture]] covers physical expressions such as technology, architecture and art, whereas immaterial culture includes principles of [[social organization]], [[mythology]], [[philosophy]], [[literature]], and [[science]].<ref name=MacionisGerber2011>{{cite book |url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/sociology/oclc/652430995 |title=Sociology |last=Macionis |first=John J. |last2=Gerber |first2=Linda Marie |date=2011 |publisher=Pearson Prentice Hall |isbn=978-0137001613 |page=53 |accessdate=29 May 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818045455/https://www.worldcat.org/title/sociology/oclc/652430995 |archivedate=18 August 2017 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
The ethnobiologist Luis Ceriaco reviews the place of reptiles in culture, as studied by [[ethnoherpetology]], considering their practical uses, namely food, medicine, and other materials; their contribution to "ecological equilibrium", the [[balance of nature]]; and negative or fearful attitudes to them (especially [[Ophidiophobia|snakes]]), causing persecution, an additional challenge for conservation. This persecution, Ceriaco states, is related to and perhaps caused by [[myth]]s and [[folklore]] about the animals.<ref name="Ceríaco2012">{{cite journal | last=Ceríaco | first=Luis MP | title=Human attitudes towards herpetofauna: The influence of folklore and negative values on the conservation of amphibians and reptiles in Portugal | journal=Journal of Ethnobiology and Ethnomedicine | volume=8 | issue=1 | year=2012 | doi=10.1186/1746-4269-8-8 | page=8}}</ref>
More broadly, [[ethnozoology]] studies the place of animals in human life, spanning topics including using animals for food, whether by [[hunting]] or by [[domestication]] and [[farming]]; animals as pets, in entertainment, and in sport; reports of mythical animals; human attitudes towards animals;<ref name="Alves2018"/> medicinal and magic religious uses;<ref name="Alves Almeida Léo Neto Vieira 2009">{{cite journal | last=Alves | first=Rômulo | last2=Almeida | first2=Waltécio | last3=Léo Neto | first3=Nivaldo | last4=Vieira | first4=Washington | last5=Santana | first5=Gindomar | title=Reptiles used for medicinal and magic religious purposes in Brazil | journal=Applied Herpetology | volume=6 | issue=3 | date=1 July 2009 | doi=10.1163/157075409x432913 | pages=257–274}}</ref> and the exploitation of traditional knowledge of animals, such as in [[conservation]].<ref name="Alves2018">{{cite book | last1=Alves | first1=Rômulo R. N. |last2=Albuquerque |first2=Ulysses P. | title=Ethnozoology : animals in our lives | publisher=Academic Press | year=2018 | isbn=978-0-12-809913-1 | oclc=1007290568}}</ref>
A more recent perspective is to view the interactions of humans and reptiles as something of "more-than-human agency", in other words the subject of a multi-species study. For example, the behaviour of crocodiles "is constructed in interaction, both between people and crocodiles, and among people";<ref name="Pooley2016">{{cite journal |last1=Pooley |first1=Simon |title=A Cultural Herpetology of Nile Crocodiles in Africa |journal=Conservation and Society |date=2016 |volume=14 |issue=4 |pages=391–405 |jstor=639326}}</ref> markedly different results depended on "institutional arrangements and attitudes towards sharing a dam with crocodiles" in different villages in Benin, where knowledge of crocodile habits reduced attacks.<ref name="Pooley2016"/><ref name="Kpéra Aarts Tossou Mensah2014">{{cite journal | last=Kpéra | first=G. Nathalie | last2=Aarts | first2=Noelle | last3=Tossou | first3=Rigobert C. | last4=Mensah | first4=Guy A. | last5=Saïdou | first5=Aliou | last6=Kossou | first6=Dansou K. | last7=Sinsin | first7=A. Brice | last8=van der Zijpp | first8=Akke J. | title=‘A pond with crocodiles never dries up’: a frame analysis of human–crocodile relationships in agro-pastoral dams in Northern Benin | journal=International Journal of Agricultural Sustainability | volume=12 | issue=3 | date=13 May 2014 | doi=10.1080/14735903.2014.909637 | pages=316–333}}</ref> <!-- This article describes the roles played by reptiles in human culture, so defined.-->
==Symbolic interactions==
===In mythology and religion=== [[File:Dragon on Longshan Temple.JPG|thumb|[[Dragon]] sculpture atop [[Mengjia Longshan Temple|Longshan Temple]], Taiwan]]
Reptiles both real, like crocodiles<ref name="Zecchi2010">{{cite book |ref=harv |last=Zecchi |first=Marco |title=Sobek of Shedet : The Crocodile God in the Fayyum in the Dynastic Period |url=https://books.google.es/books/?id=tkrQcQAACAAJ |publisher=Tau Editrice |year=2010 |isbn=978-8862441155}}</ref> and snakes,<ref name=Deane/> and imaginary, like dragons,<ref name=Ingersoll>{{cite book |author=Ingersoll, Ernest |year=2013 |title=Dragons and Dragon Lore |publisher=Cosimo Classics |isbn=978-1616409241}}</ref> appear in mythology and religions around the world. A widespread theme is the [[World Turtle]] that supports the world; it is found in the mythologies of [[Hindu mythology|Hinduism]], [[Chinese mythology|China]] and [[mythologies of the indigenous peoples of the Americas|the Americas]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Tylor |first1=Edward Burnett |title=Researches Into the Early History of Mankind and the Development of Civilization |date=1870 |publisher=John Murray |pages=340–343 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=wlYrdiyYIXEC&pg=PA340&lpg=PA340}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rappengluck |first1=M. |title=The whole world put between to shells: The cosmic symbolism of tortoises and turtles |journal=Mediterranean Archaeology and Archaeometry |date=2006 |volume=6 |issue=3 |pages=223–230 |url=http://maajournal.com/Issues/2006/Vol06-3/Full26.pdf}}</ref> Romulo Alves and colleagues recorded the use of 13 species of reptiles (crocodilians and snakes) in Brazil for magic religious purposes such as [[magic spell]]s, attracting sexual partners, and as [[amulet]]s to protect against the [[evil eye]].<ref name="Alves Almeida Léo Neto Vieira 2009"/>
A [[dragon]] is a [[legendary creature]], typically with [[serpentine shape|snake-like]] or [[reptile|reptilian]] traits, in the [[myths]] of both [[European dragon|European]] and [[Chinese dragon|Chinese]] cultures, with counterparts in [[Japanese dragon|Japan]], Korea and other East Asian countries.<ref name=Ingersoll/> The (genuine) [[plesiosaur]] ''[[Woolungasaurus]]'' is named after the Woolunga, a mythical reptile of Australia.<ref>Persson, P.O., 1960, "Lower Cretaceous Plesiosaurians (Reptilia) from Australia", ''Lunds Universitets Arsskrift'' '''56'''(12): 1-23</ref> In [[Greek mythology]] snakes are associated with deadly antagonists, as a [[chthonic]] symbol, roughly translated as 'earthbound'. The nine-headed [[Lernaean Hydra]] that [[Hercules]] defeated and the three [[Gorgon]] sisters are children of [[Gaia (mythology)|Gaia]], the earth. [[Medusa]] was one of the three Gorgon sisters who [[Perseus]] defeated. Medusa is described as a hideous mortal, with snakes instead of hair and the power to turn men to stone with her gaze. After killing her, Perseus gave her head to [[Athena]] who fixed it to her shield called the [[Aegis]]. The [[Titan (mythology)|Titans]] are also depicted in art with snakes instead of legs and feet for the same reason—they are children of Gaia and [[Uranus (mythology)|Uranus]], so they are bound to the earth.<ref name="BF85"/>
[[File:Kom Ombo, Sobek 0320.JPG|thumb|upright|left|The [[Ancient Egypt]]ian [[crocodile]]-headed god, [[Sobek]]]]
Crocodiles have appeared in religions across the world. [[Ancient Egypt]] had [[Sobek]], the crocodile-headed god, with his cult-city [[Crocodilopolis]], as well as [[Taweret]], the goddess of childbirth and fertility, with the back and tail of a crocodile.<ref name="Zecchi2010"/> In [[Hinduism]], [[Varuna]], a [[Historical Vedic religion|Vedic]] and Hindu god, rides a [[Makara (Hindu mythology)|makara]], a water-beast like a crocodile,<ref>{{cite web |last1=Rodrigues |first1=Hillary |title=Vedic Deities {{!}} Varuna |url=http://www.mahavidya.ca/2008/06/22/varuna/ |publisher=Mahavidya |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="Bhattacharji1970">{{cite book |last=Bhattacharji |first=Sukumari |title=The Indian Theogony: A Comparative Study of Indian Mythology from the Vedas to the Puranas |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lDc9AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA39 |year=1970 |publisher=CUP Archive |page=39 |id=GGKEY:0GBP50CQXWN}}</ref> and he is called Nāgarāja, lord of snakes.<ref name="Bhattacharji1970"/> Similarly the goddess personifications of the [[Ganges|Ganga]] and [[Yamuna]] rivers are often depicted as riding crocodiles.<ref>{{cite web | title=Holy Rivers, Lakes, and Oceans | work=Heart of Hinduism | publisher=ISKCON Educational Services | year=2004 | url=http://hinduism.iskcon.org/practice/504.htm | quote=Most rivers are considered female and are personified as goddesses. Ganga, who features in the Mahabharata, is usually shown riding on a crocodile (see right). | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141014184216/http://hinduism.iskcon.org/practice/504.htm | archivedate=2014-10-14 | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | title=Ganga The River Goddess - Tales in Art and Mythology | date=August 2003 | first=Nitin | last=Kumar | url=http://www.exoticindiaart.com/article/ganga/ }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Hindu gods and their holy mounts | publisher=Sri. Venkateswara Zoological Park | url=http://svzoo.org/html/anicult2.htm | quote=The river goddesses, Ganga and Yamuna, were appropriately mounted on a tortoise and a crocodile respectively. | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140623165912/http://svzoo.org/html/anicult2.htm | archivedate=2014-06-23 | df= }}</ref> In [[Goa]], crocodile worship is practised, as at the annual ''Mannge Thapnee'' ceremony.<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Crocodile is God in Goa |journal=Crocodile Specialist Group Newsletter |date=January–March 1995 |volume=14 |issue=1 |page=8 |url=http://www.iucncsg.org/365_docs/attachments/protarea/CSG%20-96e3654b.pdf}}</ref> In Latin America, [[Cipactli]] was the giant earth crocodile of the [[Aztec]] and other [[Nahua peoples]].<ref name="Neumann pp. 1–22">{{cite journal | last=Neumann | first=Franke J. | title=The Dragon and the Dog: Two Symbols of Time in Nahuatl Religion | journal=Numen | volume=22 | issue=1 | date=1 January 1975 | doi=10.1163/156852775x00103 | pages=1–22}}</ref>
[[File:Awatoceanofmilk01 - color corrected.JPG|thumb|upright|Bas-relief from [[Angkor Wat]] with [[Samudra manthan]]-Vishnu in the centre above his [[turtle]] [[avatar]], [[Kurma]]]]
In Hinduism, [[snake worship|snakes are worshipped]] as gods. The cobra is seen around the neck of [[Shiva]], while [[Vishnu]] is often depicted as sleeping on a seven-headed snake or within the coils of a serpent. There are temples in India solely for cobras, which are sometimes called ''Nagraj'' (King of Snakes), and it is believed that snakes are symbols of fertility. In the annual Hindu festival of [[Nag Panchami]], snakes are venerated and prayed to, and given gifts of milk, sweets, flowers, and lamps.<ref name=Deane>{{cite book |last=Deane |first=John |authorlink=The Worship of the Serpent |title=The Worship of the Serpent |publisher=Kessinger Publishing |year =1833 |url =http://www.sacred-texts.com/etc/wos/index.htm |isbn=1-56459-898-5 |pages=61–64}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= Verma |first=Manish |title=Fasts & Festivals Of India |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z4gzFFLdBoYC&pg=PA37 |year=2000 |publisher=Diamond Pocket Books |isbn=978-81-7182-076-4 |pages=37–38}}</ref>
In religious terms, the snake rivals the [[jaguar]] in importance in ancient [[Mesoamerica]]. "In states of ecstasy, lords dance a serpent dance; great descending snakes adorn and support buildings from [[Chichen Itza]] to [[Tenochtitlan]], and the [[Nahuatl]] word ''coatl'' meaning serpent or twin, forms part of primary deities such as [[Mixcoatl]], [[Quetzalcoatl]], and [[Coatlicue]]."<ref>{{cite book |author=Miller, Mary |title=The Gods and Symbols of Ancient Mexico and the Maya |year=1993 |publisher=Thames & Hudson |isbn=978-0-500-27928-1}}</ref>
In Christianity and Judaism, a serpent appears in Genesis 3:1 to tempt [[Adam and Eve]] with the [[forbidden fruit]] from the [[Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil|Tree of Knowledge]].<ref>"Now the serpent was more subtil than any beast of the field which the Lord God had made. And he said unto the woman, Yea, hath God said, Ye shall not eat of every tree of the garden?" ''[[King James Version]]'', [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] 3:1</ref> In [[Neo-Paganism]] and [[Wicca]], the snake is seen as a symbol of wisdom and knowledge. A legend tells that [[Saint Patrick]] banished snakes from Ireland; there are no extant native snakes there.<ref name="news.nationalgeographic.com">{{cite web|title=Snakeless in Ireland: Blame Ice Age, Not St. Patrick|first=James|last= Owen|date=March 13, 2008 |website=National Geographic News|accessdate=17 March 2011|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2008/03/080313-snakes-ireland.html}}</ref> The legend of [[Saint George and the Dragon]], which has pre-Christian origins, tells that the saint, often depicted on horseback and armed with a lance, killed a dragon.<ref>[http://d.lib.rochester.edu/teams/text/whatley-saints-lives-in-middle-english-collections-st-george-and-the-dragon St. George and the Dragon: Introduction] in: E. Gordon Whatley, Anne B. Thompson, Robert K. Upchurch (eds.), ''Saints' Lives in Middle English Collections'' (2004).</ref>
More recently, the [[contemporary legend|urban legend]] of New York [[sewer alligator]]s holds that pet reptiles, released when they grew too large for their owners' comfort, thrived and grew to monstrous size beneath the city's streets.<ref>{{cite journal | author1=Fergus, George | authorlink=Fergus G. | title=More on Alligators in the Sewers | jstor=541011 | journal=The Journal of American Folklore | volume=55 | page=8 | year=1989 | issue=988 | doi=10.2307/541011}}</ref>
[[File:Rod of Asclepius2.svg|thumb|upright=0.3|The [[serpent (symbolism)|serpent]]-entwined [[Rod of Asclepius]], a symbol of [[medicine]]]]
===As symbols=== {{further|Serpent (symbolism)}}
The snake or serpent has played a powerful [[Serpent (symbolism)|symbolic role]] in different cultures. In [[History of Egypt|Egyptian history]], the Nile cobra adorned the crown of the [[pharaoh]]. It was [[snake worship|worshipped]] as one of the gods and was also used for sinister purposes: murder of an adversary and ritual suicide ([[Cleopatra VII of Egypt|Cleopatra]]).<ref name=BF85>{{cite book |last=Bullfinch |first=Thomas |authorlink=Thomas Bullfinch |title=Bullfinch's Complete Mythology |publisher=Chancellor Press |year=2000 |location=London |url=http://etext.library.adelaide.edu.au/b/bulfinch/thomas/ |isbn=0-7537-0381-5 |page=85 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090209004721/http://etext.library.adelaide.edu.au/b/bulfinch/thomas/ |archivedate=2009-02-09 |df= }}</ref> In America, the snake has served as a symbol of deceptiveness, as when US President [[Andrew Jackson]] told the [[Creek Nation]] in 1829 that he spoke with a straight tongue, not a [[forked tongue|forked one]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Foster |first=Thomas Flournoy |title=Speech on the Bill to Provide for the Removal of the Indians, West of the Mississippi: Delivered in the House of Representatives of the United States, May 17, 1830 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QD4vAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA11 |year=1830 |publisher=D. Green |page=11}}</ref>
Three medical symbols involving snakes, still used today, are the [[Bowl of Hygieia]] symbolizing pharmacy, and the [[Caduceus]] and [[Rod of Asclepius]], symbols of medicine.<ref name=AIM>{{cite journal |last=Wilcox |first=Robert A. |last2=Whitham |first2= Emma M|title=The symbol of modern medicine: why one snake is more than two |date=15 April 2003 |pages=673–7 |issue=8 |volume=138 |url=http://www.annals.org/cgi/content/full/138/8/673 |journal=Annals of Internal Medicine |accessdate=26 November 2007 | pmid=12693891 |doi=10.7326/0003-4819-138-8-200304150-00016}}</ref>
The [[ouroboros]] is a widely used symbol, claimed to be related to [[alchemy]]. It is depicted as a coiled snake eating its own tail, representing the cycle of [[Dying god|life, death and rebirth]]. The [[Snake (zodiac)|snake]] is one of the 12 celestial animals of the [[Chinese Zodiac]]. Ancient Peruvian cultures often depicted snakes.<ref>{{cite book | last=Benson |first= Elizabeth | title= The Mochica: A Culture of Peru |location=London | publisher=Thames and Hudson |year= 1972 | isbn= 0-500-72001-0 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last1=Berrin |first1= Katherine |last2= Larco Museum |title=The Spirit of Ancient Peru: Treasures from the [[Larco Museum|Museo Arqueológico Rafael Larco Herrera]] | location= New York |publisher= Thames and Hudson |year= 1997 |isbn=978-0-500-01802-6 }}</ref>
The [[Cultural depictions of turtles|tortoise]] was a fertility symbol in ancient Greece and Rome, and an attribute of [[Aphrodite]]/[[Venus (mythology)|Venus]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Bevan |first=Elinor |title=Ancient Deities and Tortoise-Representations in Sanctuaries |journal=The Annual of the British School at Athens |year=1988 |volume=83 |pages=1–6 |doi=10.1017/s006824540002058x}}</ref> The turtle has a prominent position as a symbol of steadfastness and tranquility in religion, mythology, and folklore from around the world.<ref name=Plotkin>Plotkin, Pamela, T., 2007, ''Biology and Conservation of Ridley Sea Turtles'', Johns Hopkins University, {{ISBN|0-8018-8611-2}}.</ref> A tortoise's longevity is suggested by its long lifespan and its shell, which was thought to protect it from any foe.<ref name=Ball>Ball, Catherine, 2004, ''Animal Motifs in Asian Art'', Courier Dover Publications, {{ISBN|0-486-43338-2}}.</ref> In the [[cosmological myth]]s of several cultures a ''[[World Turtle]]'' carries the world upon its back or supports the heavens.<ref name=Stookey>Stookey, Lorena Laura, 2004, ''Thematic Guide to World Mythology'', Greenwood Press, {{ISBN|0-313-31505-1}}.</ref>
===In literature=== [[File:Illustration at p. 73 in Just So Stories (c1912).png|thumb|"How the elephant got his trunk" in [[Rudyard Kipling]]'s 1902 ''[[Just So Stories]]'']] {{further|List of fictional reptiles}}
Reptiles have appeared in literature since ancient times. [[Pliny the Elder]], for instance, describes the legendary [[basilisk]] as a snake "twelve fingers in length".<ref>Pliny, viii. 33, translated {{cite book |title=The Natural History |author=Pliny the Elder |authorlink=Pliny the Elder |editor=[[John Bostock (physician)|Bostock, John]], [[Henry Thomas Riley|Riley, Henry Thomas]] (translators) |year=1855 |url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0137;query=chapter%3D%23357;layout=;loc=8.33}}</ref> The animal reappears many times in Western literature, including in [[Isidore of Seville]]'s medieval ''[[Etymologiae]]'',<ref>{{cite book |last=Isidore of Seville |authorlink=Isidore of Seville |title=The Etymologies of Isidore of Seville |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3ep502syZv8C&pg=PA255 |year=2006 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-1-139-45616-6 |page=255}}</ref> and more recently in [[J. K. Rowling]]'s 1998 ''[[Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets]]''.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Miller |first1=Leah |title=The Basilisk |url=https://blogs.royalsociety.org/history-of-science/2017/06/28/the-basilisk/ |publisher=[[The Royal Society]] |accessdate=31 August 2018 |date=28 June 2017}}</ref> Among the many other reptiles in children's literature, [[Rudyard Kipling]]'s story "How the Elephant got his Trunk" in his 1902 book ''[[Just So Stories]]'' features a crocodile who grips and stretches the elephant's nose.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Du Toit |first1=Adele |title=How the elephant got his trunk — classic story plays out in Kruger |url=https://www.news24.com/Archives/Witness/How-the-elephant-got-his-trunk-classic-story-plays-out-in-Kruger-20150430 |publisher=News24 |accessdate=15 August 2018 |date=30 December 2014}}</ref>
Turtles and tortoises feature in books for children and adults, from [[The Tortoise and the Hare]] in [[Aesop's Fables]]<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ashliman |first1=D. L. |title=The Tortoise and the Hare and other races between unequal contestants |url=https://www.pitt.edu/~dash/type0275.html |publisher=University of Pittsburgh |accessdate=7 October 2018 |date=2011}}</ref> to Alderman Ptolemy Tortoise in [[Beatrix Potter]]'s ''[[The Tale of Mr. Jeremy Fisher]]'' and Br'er Turtle in [[Uncle Remus]]'s folktales. In [[Stephen King]]'s [[Dark Tower Series|''The Dark Tower'' series]], the world was created by the turtle Maturin, one of the guardians of the tower.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Miller |first1=Matt |title=There Are Two Important Clues in It That Only Real Stephen King Fans Will Notice |url=https://www.esquire.com/entertainment/movies/a12231483/stephen-king-it-movie-turtle-details/ |publisher=Esquire |accessdate=31 August 2018 |date=13 September 2017}}</ref>
Snakes, too, have played a role in literature since ancient Rome, where Cadmus kills a gigantic serpent in [[Ovid]]'s ''[[Metamorphoses]]'', and as prophesied is transformed into a snake. The [[Cleopatra|eponymous heroine]] in [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Antony and Cleopatra]]'' kills herself with an [[asp viper]], while [[John Milton]]'s ''[[Paradise Lost]]'' describes [[Satan]] as a mighty serpent, "Fold above fold a surging Maze his Head / Crested aloft, and Carbuncle his Eyes; / With burnisht Neck of verdant Gold, erect / Amidst his circling Spires."<ref name="Mullan">{{cite web |last1=Mullan |first1=John |authorlink1=John Mullan |title=Ten of the best {{!}} Snakes in literature |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/jul/08/ten-best-snakes |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=31 August 2018 |date=8 July 2011}}</ref> In [[D. H. Lawrence]]'s ''Snake'', the thirsty poet is forced to wait while the snake "sipped with his straight mouth, / Softly drank through his straight gums, into his slack long body, / Silently."<ref name="Mullan"/> Among the novels that feature snakes, [[Lemony Snicket]]'s 1999 ''[[The Reptile Room]]'' tells of a herpetologist who cares for orphaned children and dies of snakebite, while [[Barbara Kingsolver]]'s 1998 thriller ''[[The Poisonwood Bible]]'' portrays a missionary in the Congo, who is greeted by the planting of deadly snakes in his friend's houses, and then his own.<ref name="Mullan"/>
The supposed weeping of insincere [[crocodile tears]] is derived from an ancient anecdote that crocodiles weep to lure their prey, or that they [[Crying|cry]] for the victims they are eating, first told in the ninth century ''[[Bibliotheca (Photius)|Bibliotheca]]'' by [[Photios]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Bibliothèque. Tome VIII : Codices 257-280. |last=Photius |others=R. Henry (trans.) |year=1977 |publisher=Les Belles Lettres |language=French, Ancient Greek |isbn=978-2-251-32227-8 |page=93}}</ref> The story is repeated in bestiaries such as [[List of medieval bestiaries#DeBestiis|''De bestiis et aliis rebus'']]. This tale was first spread widely in English in the stories of the travels of [[Sir John Mandeville]] in the 14th century, and appears in several of Shakespeare's plays.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=8-KxOZWvNdgC&pg=PT185 |title=Curious creatures in zoology |author=Ashton, John |isbn=978-1-4092-3184-4 |year=2009}}</ref> In fact, crocodiles can generate tears, but they do not cry.<ref>[http://crocodilian.com/cnhc/cbd-faq-q6.htm Britton, Adam (n.d.). Do crocodiles cry 'crocodile tears'?] ''Crocodilian Biology Database''. Retrieved March 13, 2006 from the Crocodile Specialist Group, Crocodile Species List, FAQ.</ref>
===In art===
Reptiles including crocodiles, lizards, snakes, and [[Cultural depictions of turtles|tortoises]] have been portrayed by artists since ancient times, using media as varied as fresco, ceramic, marble, jewellery, and oil on canvas. This has sometimes been for their [[Serpent (symbolism)|symbolism, as with snakes]].<ref name="MMA">{{cite web |last1=Kjellgren |first1=Eric |title=Crocodiles |url=https://www.metmuseum.org/connections/crocodiles |publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] |accessdate=22 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Lesser |first1=Casey |title=The Renaissance Artist Who Cast Live Snakes, Frogs, and Lizards to Make His Ceramics |url=https://www.artsy.net/article/artsy-editorial-renaissance-artist-cast-live-snakes-frogs-lizards-ceramics |website=Artsy.net |accessdate=22 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Jenkins|first1=Tibbs|title=Jewellery {{!}}The snake in culture and art|url=http://www.tatler.com/article/the-snake-in-culture-and-art|accessdate=22 January 2018|work=[[The Tatler]]|date=17 March 2016}}</ref> [[M. C. Escher#Tessellation|M. C. Escher explored tessellation]]s in his graphic art using lizards and snakes among other animals.<ref>{{cite book |author=Locher, J. L. |year=1971 |title=The World of M. C. Escher |publisher=[[Abrams Books|Abrams]] |isbn=0-451-79961-5 |pages=79–85}}</ref>
<gallery mode="packed" heights="150px"> File:Tortoise figurine MET DP222644 (cropped).jpg|Tortoise figurine, [[ceramic]], Near East, 3rd millennium BC File:Fresco Nile Architecture Mask MANN 8607.jpg |River scene with crocodile. [[Fresco]] from [[Pompeii]], 62–79 AD File:Roman - Roman Snake Ring - Walters 572163 - Three Quarter.jpg|Roman snake ring, 1st century AD File:Apollo Saurocton Louvre (cropped).jpg |''[[Apollo]] the lizard-killer'' (detail), [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] copy of [[Praxiteles]], 4th century BC File:Agnolo Bronzino - The adoration of the bronze snake - Google Art Project (27465014).jpg |''The adoration of the bronze snake'' by [[Agnolo Bronzino]], c. 1545 File:Boy Bitten by a Lizard-Caravaggio (Longhi).jpg |''Boy Bitten by a Lizard'' by [[Caravaggio]], c. 1595 File:Peter Paul Rubens - Hippopotamus and Crocodile Hunt (Alte Pinakothek).jpg |''Hippopotamus and Crocodile Hunt'' by [[Peter Paul Rubens]], c. 1616 File:Tornai Nudes with Tortoise.jpg |''Nudes with Tortoise'' by [[Gyula Tornai]] (1861–1928) File:Painting - Google Art Project.jpg |[[Australian aboriginal]] painting with lizards and snake, 1900–1970 File:Sandsculpting, Frankston, Vic jjron, 21.01.2009.jpg |[[Sand art and play|Sandsculpted]] dinosaurs in Australia, 2009
</gallery>
===Depictions of dinosaurs=== [[File:Sydenham studio.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The [[Crystal Palace Dinosaurs]] under construction at [[Benjamin Waterhouse Hawkins]]' studio in [[Sydenham]], c. 1853]] {{main|Cultural depictions of dinosaurs}}
Dinosaurs have been widely depicted in culture since the English palaeontologist [[Richard Owen]] coined the name ''[[dinosaur]]'' in 1842. As soon as 1854, a group of life-sized models, the [[Crystal Palace Dinosaurs]], were on display to the public in south London.<ref name=Torrens>Torrens, Hugh. "Politics and Paleontology". ''The Complete Dinosaur,'' 175–190.</ref><ref name=Glut>{{cite book |last=Glut |first=Donald F. |authorlink=Donald F. Glut |author2=Brett-Surman, Michael K. |year=1997 |chapter=Dinosaurs and the media |title=The Complete Dinosaur |publisher=Indiana University Press |pages=675–706 |isbn=0-253-33349-0}}</ref> One dinosaur appeared in literature even earlier, as [[Charles Dickens]] placed a ''[[Megalosaurus]]'' in the first chapter of his novel ''[[Bleak House]]'' in 1852<!--the rest of the book appearing in stages in subsequent months-->.<ref>"''London. Michaelmas term lately over, and the Lord Chancellor sitting in Lincoln's Inn Hall. Implacable November weather. As much mud in the streets, as if the waters had but newly retired from the face of the earth, and it would not be wonderful to meet a Megalosaurus, forty feet long or so, waddling like an elephantine lizard up Holborne Hill.''" From page 1 of Dickens, Charles J.H. (1852). ''[[s:Bleak House/Chapter I|Bleak House, Chapter I: In Chancery]]''. London: Bradbury & Evans.</ref>
The dinosaurs featured in books, films, television programs, artwork, and other media have been used for both education and entertainment. The depictions range from the realistic, as in the television [[documentary film|documentaries]] of the 1990s and first decade of the 21st century, or the fantastic, as in the [[monster movie]]s of the 1950s and 1960s such as ''[[Q (film)|Q – The Winged Serpent]]''.<ref name=Glut/><ref name=Gregory/><ref name=Searles>{{cite book |last=Searles |first=Baird |title=Films of Science Fiction and Fantasy |pages=104–116 |chapter= Dinosaurs and others |year= 1988|publisher=AFI Press |location=New York |isbn=0-8109-0922-7}}</ref> These were followed by [[Steven Spielberg]]'s highly successful<ref>[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/jurassic_park Jurassic Park – Movie Reviews, Trailers, Pictures – Rotten Tomatoes]. Rottentomatoes.com. Retrieved on 2012-09-04.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=main&id=jurassicpark.htm|title=Jurassic Park (1993) - Box Office Mojo|website=www.boxofficemojo.com}}</ref> 1993 ''[[Jurassic Park]]'', a film adaptation of [[Michael Crichton]]'s [[Jurassic Park (novel)|1990 novel]], and its sequels, based on the idea of bringing a terrifying beast back from [[extinction]] by cloning from [[ancient DNA|fossil DNA]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.michaelcrichton.net/books-jurassicpark.html|title=Jurassic Park|publisher=MichaelCrichton.com|accessdate=January 1, 2009}}</ref> Critics have noticed that ''Jurassic Park'' echoes themes from [[Mary Shelley]]'s ''[[Frankenstein]]'', the aggressive and cunning ''[[Velociraptor]]'' taking the place of [[Frankenstein's monster]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Debus|first=Allen A.|title=Dinosaurs in Fantastic Fiction: A Thematic Survey|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N8qXUT06WucC&pg=PA140|year=2006|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-2672-0|pages=124–146}}</ref>
[[File:Laelaps-Charles Knight-1897.jpg|thumb|The 1897 painting of fighting "''Laelaps''" (now ''[[Dryptosaurus]]'') by [[Charles R. Knight]]]]
The growth in interest in dinosaurs since the [[Dinosaur Renaissance]] has been accompanied by depictions made by artists working with ideas at the leading edge of dinosaur science, presenting lively dinosaurs and [[feathered dinosaur]]s as these concepts were first being considered. Cultural depictions of dinosaurs have been an important means of making scientific discoveries accessible to the public.<ref name=Gregory>{{cite book |last=Paul |first=Gregory S. |authorlink=Gregory S. Paul |editor=Paul, Gregory S. |title=The [[Scientific American]] Book of Dinosaurs |year=2000 |publisher=St. Martin's Press |isbn=0-312-26226-4 |pages=113–118 |chapter=The Art of Charles R. Knight}}</ref>
Cultural depictions have created or reinforced misconceptions about dinosaurs and other prehistoric animals, such as inaccurately and anachronistically portraying a sort of "prehistoric world" where many kinds of extinct animals (from the [[Permian]] animal ''[[Dimetrodon]]'' to [[mammoth]]s and [[caveman|cavemen]]) lived together, with dinosaurs living lives of constant combat.<ref name=Glut/><ref>{{cite book | last=Lucas |first=Spencer G. |authorlink=Spencer G. Lucas |year=2000 |title=Dinosaurs: The Textbook |edition=3rd |chapter=Dinosaurs in the public eye |publisher=McGraw-Hill |pages=247–260 |isbn=0-07-303642-0 }}</ref>
Other misconceptions reinforced by cultural depictions came from a scientific consensus that has now been overturned, such as the alternate usage of ''dinosaur'' to describe something that is maladapted or obsolete, or dinosaurs as slow and unintelligent.<ref name=Glut/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=dinosaur |title=dinosaur |work=Dictionary.com |publisher=Lexico |accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref>
==Practical interactions== ===Food and other products=== [[File:Handbag of West African Dwarf Crocodile.JPG|thumb|Handbag made from West African dwarf crocodile (''[[Osteolaemus tetraspis]]'') skin at the [[Natural History Museum, London]]]]
Crocodiles and alligators are [[crocodile farm|farmed commercially]]. Their hides are [[Tanning (leather)|tanned]] and used to make leather goods such as shoes and [[handbag]]s; crocodile meat is also considered a delicacy.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/30/us/anahuac-journal-alligator-farmer-feeds-demand-for-all-the-parts.html |title=Anahuac Journal; Alligator Farmer Feeds Demand for All the Parts |work=The New York Times |date=30 November 1998 |last=Lyman |first=Rick |accessdate=13 November 2013}}</ref> The most commonly farmed species are the saltwater and Nile crocodiles. Farming has resulted in an increase in the saltwater crocodile population in [[Australia]], as eggs are usually harvested from the wild, so landowners have an incentive to conserve their habitat. Crocodile [[leather]] is made into wallets, briefcases, purses, handbags, belts, hats, and shoes. [[Crocodile oil]] has been used for various purposes.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=FUaaDBFsYFEC&pg=PA56&dq=%22crocodile+oil%22&lr=&sig=ACfU3U0FmNFQ2vDA8zdrkNJj6CApHYWZxQ Country Folk Medicine: Tales of Skunk Oil, Sassafras Tea, and Other Old-time Remedies] (2004) Elisabeth Janos. p. 56.</ref>
Crocodile meat is occasionally eaten as an "exotic" delicacy in the western world.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Armstrong |first1=Hilary |title=Best exotic restaurants in London |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/restaurants/best-exotic-restaurants-in-london-6863561.html |publisher=[[Evening Standard]] |accessdate=4 September 2016 |date=8 April 2009}}</ref> [[Alligator meat]] is farmed for human consumption in the United States.<ref name="MartinCarter2000">{{cite book |last1=Martin |first1=Roy E. |last2=Carter |first2=Emily Paine |last3=Flick |first3=George J., Jr. |author4=Davis, Lynn M. |title=Marine and Freshwater Products Handbook |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OFKLk3S0fzgC&pg=PA277 |year=2000 |publisher=CRC Press |isbn=978-1-56676-889-4 |page=277}}</ref><ref name="Raichlen1993">{{cite book |last=Raichlen |first=Steven |title=Miami Spice: The New Florida Cuisine |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VCFXGdAckBAC&pg=PA35|year=1993|publisher=Workman |isbn=978-1-56305-346-7 |page=35}}</ref> Turtle meat is considered a delicacy in Asian cuisine, while [[turtle soup]] was once highly prized in [[English cuisine]] also.<ref>{{cite web | last=Barzyk | first=J. E. |date=November 1999 | title=Turtles in Crisis: The Asian Food Markets | publisher=Tortoise Trust | url=http://www.tortoisetrust.org/articles/asia.html | accessdate=31 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia |title=Old fashioned turtle soup recipe |url=http://www.publicbookshelf.com/public_html/The_Household_Cyclopedia_of_General_Information/turtlesou_beh.html |work=The Household Cyclopedia of General Information |date=1881 |accessdate=31 August 2018}}</ref> Turtle [[plastron]]s (shells) are widely used in [[traditional Chinese medicine]]; hundreds of tons of them are imported into Taiwan each year.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Chen | first1 = T.-H. | year = 2009 | last2 = Chang | first2 = H.-C. | last3 = Lue | first3 = K.-Y. | title = Unregulated Trade in Turtle Shells for Chinese Traditional Medicine in East and Southeast Asia: The Case of Taiwan | journal = Chelonian Conservation and Biology | volume = 8 | issue = 1 | pages = 11–18 | doi = 10.2744/CCB-0747.1 | url = http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.2744/CCB-0747.1}}</ref>
[[Snake soup]] is made in [[Cantonese cuisine]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Irvine |first=F. R. |year=1954 |title=Snakes as food for man |journal=British Journal of Herpetology |volume=1 |issue=10| pages=183–189}}</ref> In Indonesia, drinking snake blood is believed to increase sexual virility.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Connor |first1=Neil |title=Here's What Men in Asia Eat To Boost Their Libidos |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/heres-what-men-in-asia-eat-to-boost-their-libidos-2013-10?IR=T |publisher=Business Insider |accessdate=6 October 2018 |date=4 October 2013}}</ref> [[Snake wine]] (蛇酒) is an alcoholic beverage produced by infusing whole snakes in [[Chinese alcoholic beverages|rice wine]] or [[grain alcohol]]. The drink was first recorded to have been consumed in China during the [[Western Zhou dynasty]] and considered an important curative and believed to reinvigorate a person according to [[Traditional Chinese medicine]].<ref name=sw1>{{cite web |title=蛇酒的泡制与药用(The production and medicinal qualities of snake wine)|date=9 April 2007 |url=http://www.cn939.com/tcm-article-read-4694.html}}</ref>
===In medicine===
[[Lizard]]s such as the Gila monster produce toxins with medical applications. Gila toxin reduces plasma glucose; the substance is now synthesised for use in the anti-[[diabetes]] drug [[exenatide]] (Byetta).<ref name=Casey2013>{{cite web |last1=Casey |first1=Constance |title=Don't Call It a Monster |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/science/2013/04/gila_monster_revolting_creature_the_large_venomous_lizard_of_the_u_s_southwest.html |publisher=Slate |date=26 April 2013}}</ref> A toxin from Gila monster saliva has been studied for use as an anti-[[Alzheimer's]] drug.<ref>{{cite web|title=Alzheimer's research seeks out lizards|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/1912396.stm|publisher=BBC|date=5 April 2002}}</ref>
The [[cytotoxic]] effect of snake venom is being researched as a potential treatment for cancers.<ref>{{Cite journal|pmc=3627178 | journal=Asian Pacific Journal of Tropical Medicine| volume=3| issue=2| pages=156–162|title=Theraputic potential of snake venom in cancer therapy: current perspective|date=February 2012|author=Vivek Kumar Vyas, Keyur Brahmbahtt, Ustav Parmar| last2=Brahmbhatt| last3=Bhatt| last4=Parmar| doi=10.1016/S2221-1691(13)60042-8| pmid=23593597}}</ref>
Reptiles including crocodilians, snakes, turtles, and lizards are used in [[traditional medicine]] in Brazil for a wide range of conditions including [[asthma]], headache, [[herpes zoster]], [[impotence]], infections, [[jaundice]], [[respiratory disease]]s, snake bite, [[thrombosis]], toothache, and wounds.<ref name="Alves Almeida Léo Neto Vieira 2009"/>
===As threats=== [[File:Snake in basket.jpg|thumb|upright|An [[Indian cobra]] in a basket with a [[snake charmer]]]] {{main|Snakebite|Crocodile attack}}
Deaths from [[snakebite]]s are uncommon in many parts of the world, but are still counted in tens of thousands per year in India.<ref name="Sinha">{{Cite news | last=Sinha| first=Kounteya| title=No more the land of snake charmers... | newspaper=The Times of India| date =25 July 2006| url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/articleshow/1803026.cms}}</ref> Snakebite can be treated with [[antivenom]] made from the venom of the snake. To produce antivenom, a mixture of the venoms of different species of snake is injected into the body of a horse in ever-increasing dosages until the horse is immunized. Blood is then extracted; the serum is separated, purified and freeze-dried.<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2146932/pdf/canfamphys00081-0113.pdf |title= Rattlesnake bite in a patient with horse allergy and von Willebrand's disease: case report |pmc=2146932 |pmid=8939322 |volume=42 |year=1996 |journal=Can Fam Physician |pages=2207–11}}</ref>
Large crocodiles, especially the [[saltwater crocodile]] and [[Nile crocodile]], [[crocodile attacks|attack and kill]] hundreds of people each year in Southeast Asia and Africa.<ref name=iucncsg>{{cite web |title=Crocodilian Attacks|url=http://www.iucncsg.org/pages/Crocodilian-Attacks.html |publisher=IUCN Crocodile Specialist Group |accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref>
===For entertainment===
In India, [[snake charming]] is a traditional roadside show. The snake charmer carries a basket that contains a snake to which he plays tunes from his flute, to which the snake appears to dance.<ref name="Bagla"/> Snakes respond to the movement of the flute, not the actual noise.<ref name="Bagla">{{cite news| last=Bagla| first=Pallava| title=India's Snake Charmers Fade, Blaming Eco-Laws, TV| date=23 April 2002| work=National Geographic News| url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2002/04/0417_020423_snakecharm_2.html | accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=BumyQJ14n8sC&pg=PA482 "Snake charmer's bluff"] ''International Wildlife Encyclopedia'', 3rd edition, page 482</ref>
In the Western world, a variety of reptiles including iguanas, turtles, and some snakes (especially docile species such as the [[Python regius|ball python]] and [[corn snake]]) are kept as pets;<ref name="PasmansBogaerts2017"/><ref name=Ernest/> pond turtles were already used as pets in [[Ancient Rome|Roman times]].<ref name="Scalera2007">{{cite book |last1=Scalera |first1=Riccardo |title=An overview of the natural history of non-indigenous amphibians and reptiles |publisher=Springer |volume=2 |year=2007 |pages=141–160 |doi=10.1007/978-1-4020-6029-8_7}}</ref> Reptiles have a strong capacity for learning and can be playful. They have specialised diets and require some skill to feed; many lizards and turtles are found on veterinary inspection to be suffering from metabolic bone disease, which can be caused by poor diet or lack of ultraviolet lighting. Poisoning by venomous reptile pets is rare, but bites from large lizards like [[green iguana]]s, which are widely kept as pets in the US, are more common, with some 800 cases per year.<ref name="PasmansBogaerts2017">{{cite journal |last1=Pasmans |first1=Frank |last2=Bogaerts |first2=Serge |last3=Braeckman |first3=Johan |last4=Cunningham |first4=Andrew A |last5=Hellebuyck |first5=Tom |last6=Griffiths |first6=Richard A |last7=Sparreboom |first7=Max |last8=Schmidt |first8=Benedikt R |last9=Martel |first9=An |title=Future of keeping pet reptiles and amphibians: towards integrating animal welfare, human health and environmental sustainability |journal=Veterinary Record |volume=181|issue=17|year=2017 |pages=450–450 |doi=10.1136/vr.104296}}</ref><ref name=Ernest>{{cite book |last=Ernest |first=Carl |author2=George R. Zug |author3=Molly Dwyer Griffin |title=Snakes in Question: The Smithsonian Answer Book | publisher=Smithsonian Books |year=1996 |page=203 |isbn=1-56098-648-4 }}</ref>
===Persecution and conservation=== [[File:Pantherophis obsoletus UMFS 2016.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Snakes like this [[Pantherophis obsoletus|Western rat snake]] are often killed, accidentally or intentionally, on roads.]]
Cultural attitudes to reptiles include a widespread fear, sometimes extending to [[phobia]], especially of snakes;<ref name="Ceríaco2012"/> [[Carl Sagan]] suggested that the fear may be ancestral,<ref name=Sagan1977>{{cite book |author=Sagan, Carl |authorlink=Carl Sagan |title=[[The Dragons of Eden]]: Speculations on the Evolution of Human Intelligence |year=1977 |publisher=Ballantine Books |isbn=978-0345346292}}</ref><ref name="Ceríaco2012"/> and it is indeed shared by other [[primates]].<ref name="Ceríaco2012"/> In the US, 12% of men and 38% of women feared snakes; along with spiders, this is the most common phobia in Western societies. Negative attitudes extend in some countries to other reptiles; for example, the harmless [[gecko]] is considered to be evil and poisonous in Portugal. Such attitudes have contributed to persecution.<!--see e.g. Figure 1 in Ceriaco 2012--><ref name="Ceríaco2012"/> Folklore about reptiles, too, is correlated with negative attitudes to them. Persecution resulting from folklore and people's attitudes can thus be added to the challenge of conserving reptiles, already threatened by human activities including destruction of their habitats, [[pollution]], [[climate change]], competition with introduced [[alien species]], and excessive exploitation, such as for [[bushmeat]].<ref name="Ceríaco2012"/><ref>{{cite web |title=Bushmeat |url=https://www.cifor.org/bushmeat/ |publisher=Center for International Forestry Research |accessdate=6 October 2018}}</ref> Persecution includes the deliberate killing of snakes across Europe, and the "rounding up" of [[rattlesnake]]s in America.<ref name="Ceríaco2012"/><ref name="Weir1992">{{cite journal | last=WEIR | first=JACK | title=The Sweetwater Rattlesnake Round-Up: A Case Study in Environmental Ethics | journal=Conservation Biology | volume=6 | issue=1 | year=1992 | doi=10.1046/j.1523-1739.1992.610116.x | pages=116–127}}</ref> An experiment using fake snakes and turtles in Canada showed that snakes were run over more often than turtles, often when drivers apparently intentionally swerved to strike the snakes.<ref name="Ceríaco2012"/> In Australia, 38% of people surveyed stated that they attacked large [[elapidae|elapid snakes]] to protect children and pets, and because they feared and hated these snakes.<ref name="Ceríaco2012"/><ref name="WhitakerShine2000">{{cite journal | last=Whitaker | first=Patrick B. | last2=Shine | first2=Richard | title=Sources of Mortality of Large Elapid Snakes in an Agricultural Landscape | journal=Journal of Herpetology | publisher=JSTOR | volume=34 | issue=1 | year=2000 | doi=10.2307/1565247 | page=121}}</ref>
Several non-profit organizations around the world focus on reptile conservation, including the International Reptile Conservation Foundation,<ref>{{cite web |title=Welcome to the IRCF |url=http://www.ircf.org/ |publisher=IRCF |accessdate=6 October 2018}}</ref> and the Amphibian and Reptile Conservation Trust.<ref>{{cite web |title=Amphibian and Reptile Conservation |url=https://www.arc-trust.org/ |publisher=ARC Trust |accessdate=6 October 2018}}</ref> A peer-reviewed journal, ''Amphibian and Reptile Conservation'', publishes research on the topic.<ref>{{cite web |title=Amphibian & Reptile Conservation |url=http://amphibian-reptile-conservation.org/ |publisher=Amphibian & Reptile Conservation |accessdate=6 October 2018}}</ref>

revision.comment: Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contribs/76.3.249.166|76.3.249.166]] to version by KolbertBot. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] Thanks, [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]]. (3344665) (Bot)
revision.text:
[[File:Ice Shove Wisconsin.jpg|thumb|An ice shove on [[Lake Winnebago]] in the state of [[Wisconsin]] in March 2009]]
An '''ice shove,''' '''ice surge,''' '''ice heave,''' '''ivu,'''<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Mason | first1 = Owen | title = Living with the coast of Alaska | year = 1997 | publisher = [[Duke University Press]] | location = Durham, NC | isbn = 978-0-8223-2009-8 | page = 93 | url = https://www.dukeupress.edu/Living-with-the-Coast-of-Alaska/ | first2 = William J. | last2 = Neal | first3 = Orrin H. | last3 = Pilkey | first4 = Jane | last4 = Bullock | first5 = Ted | last5 = Fathauer | first6 = Deborah F. | last6 = Pilkey | first7 = Douglas | last7 = Swanston | accessdate = 12 December 2013 | format=cloth; also paperback ({{ISBN|978-0-8223-2019-7}}) | chapter = Wind, Ice, and Sea | series = Living with the Shore }}</ref> or '''shoreline ice pileup''' is a surge of ice from an ocean or large lake onto the [[shore]].<ref name=WLUK>{{cite web|last=Doran |first=Chad |title=Ice shoves cause damage on Lake Winnebago shoreline |url=http://www.fox11online.com/dpp/news/local/fox_cities/ice-shoves-cause-damage-on-lake-winnebago-shoreline |publisher=[[WLUK-TV]] |accessdate=January 21, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130126005230/http://www.fox11online.com/dpp/news/local/fox_cities/ice-shoves-cause-damage-on-lake-winnebago-shoreline |archivedate=January 26, 2013 |df= }}</ref> Ice shoves are caused by [[ocean current]]s, strong winds, or temperature differences pushing ice onto the shore,<ref>{{cite web|title=Glossary for the letter i|url=http://www.crh.noaa.gov/glossary.php?letter=i|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]|accessdate=January 21, 2013}}</ref> creating piles up to 12 metres (40 feet) high. Some have described them as 'ice [[tsunami]]s',<ref name="npr">{{cite web|author=All Things Considered |url=https://www.npr.org/2013/05/14/183984438/ice-shove-damages-some-manitoba-homes-beyond-repair |title='Ice Shove' Damages Some Manitoba Homes Beyond Repair |publisher=NPR |date=2013-04-24 |accessdate=2013-05-15}}</ref> but the phenomenon works like an [[iceberg]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/13/us/ice-tsunamis/index.html |title='Ice tsunamis' sweep into homes |publisher=CNN.com |date= |accessdate=2013-05-15}}</ref> Witnesses have described the shove's sound as being like that of a [[train]] or [[thunder]].<ref name=WLUK /><ref name="cbc-2013-05-13">{{cite web|date = May 13, 2013<!-- 9:31 AM CT--> |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/story/2013/05/13/mb-ochre-beach-ice-wall-manitoba.html |title=Winds whip up worry in Manitoba community hit by ice wall |publisher=[[CBC News]] |accessdate=2013-05-15}}</ref><ref name="cbc-2013-05-10">{{cite web|date = May 11, 2013 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/story/2013/05/10/mb-ochre-river-beach-ice-wave-homes.html |title=Wall of ice destroys Manitoba homes, cottages |publisher=[[CBC News]] |accessdate=2013-05-15}}</ref><ref name="npr"/> Ice shoves can damage buildings and plants that are near to the body of water.<ref name=WLUK /><ref name="npr"/><ref name="cbc-2013-05-13"/><ref name="cbc-2013-05-10"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ER2WSBtVoPw|accessdate=2014-09-08|title=Ice Tsunami..Glacier like ice moving across Mille Lacs lake, damaging houses, Minnesota}}</ref> Arctic communities can be affected by ice shoves.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mahoney|first=Andrew|last2=Eicken|first2=Hajo|last3=Shapiro|first3=Lewis|last4=Grenfell|first4=Tom C.|date=2004-03-01|title=Ice motion and driving forces during a spring ice shove on the Alaskan Chukchi coast|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/igsoc/jog/2004/00000050/00000169/art00004|journal=Journal of Glaciology|volume=50|issue=169|pages=195–207|doi=10.3189/172756504781830141}}</ref>
