==Military== *[[Percussion ignition]] *[[Turret ship]] – Although designs for a rotating gun turret date back to the late 18th century, {{HMS|Trusty|1855|6}} was the first warship to be outfitted with one. *[[Battle Tank]]/The [[tank]] – Developed and first used in combat by the British during World War I as a means to break the deadlock of trench warfare. Attributed to [[Ernest Dunlop Swinton]] *[[Fighter aircraft]] – The [[Vickers F.B.5]] Gunbus of 1914 was the first of its kind. *[[Congreve rocket]] – [[William Congreve (inventor)|William Congreve]] *[[Harrier Jump Jet]] – [[VTOL]] ([[Vertical take-off and landing]] aircraft) *[[Aircraft carrier]] – {{HMS|Argus|I49|6}} *[[Dreadnought]] battleship – {{HMS|Dreadnought|1906|6}} *[[Bailey Bridge]] – [[Donald Bailey (civil engineer)|Donald Bailey]] *[[Chobham armour]] *[[Livens Projector]] – [[William Howard Livens]]<ref>The Use Of Gas In The Field, 1940</ref> *[[H2S radar]] (airborne radar to aid bomb targeting) – [[Alan Blumlein]] *[[Bouncing bomb]] – [[Barnes Wallis]] *[[Fuse (explosives)|Safety fuse]] – [[William Bickford (1774–1834)|William Bickford]] *[[Fairbairn-Sykes Fighting Knife]] – [[William Ewart Fairbairn]] and [[Eric A. Sykes]] *[[Armstrong Gun]] – Sir [[William Armstrong, 1st Baron Armstrong|William Armstrong]] *[[High explosive squash head]] – Sir [[Charles Dennistoun Burney]] *[[Nuclear fission]] [[chain reaction]] – [[Leo Szilard]] whilst crossing the road near [[Russell Square]]. *[[Shrapnel shell]] – [[Henry Shrapnel]] *[[Bullpup]] firearm configuration – [[Thorneycroft carbine]] *[[Puckle Gun]] – [[James Puckle]] *The side by side [[Boxlock action]], AKA the [[double barreled shotgun]] – Anson and Deeley *[[Stun grenades]] – invented by the [[Special Air Service]] in the 1960s. *[[Mills bomb]]{{spaced ndash}}the first modern fragmentation grenade. * Smokeless propellant to replace gunpowder with the use of [[Cordite]] – [[Frederick Abel]] *[[Rubber bullet]] and [[Plastic bullet]] – Developed by the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] during [[The Troubles]] in Northern Ireland. *[[Depth charge]] *[[Torpedo]] – [[Robert Whitehead]] *The [[Whitworth rifle]], considered the first [[sniper rifle]]. During the [[American Civil War]] the Whitworth rifle had been known to kill at ranges of about {{convert|800|yd|m}} – Sir [[Joseph Whitworth]] *The world's first practical underwater active sound detection apparatus, the [[ASDIC]] Active [[Sonar]] – Developed by Canadian physicist [[Robert William Boyle]] and English physicist [[Albert Beaumont Wood]] *The first self-powered machine gun [[Maxim gun]] – [[Sir Hiram Maxim]], Although the Inventor is American, the [[Maxim gun]] was financed by Albert Vickers of [[Vickers Limited]] company and produced in [[Hatton Garden]] [[London]] *Steam catapult-Commander Colin C. Mitchell RNVR *[[Self-propelled gun]] - The [[Gun Carrier Mark I]] was the first piece of [[Self-propelled artillery]] ever to be produced. *[[Special forces]] – [[Special Air Service|SAS]] Founded by [[David Stirling|Sir David Stirling]].
==Mining== *[[Tunnel boring machine]] – [[James Henry Greathead]] and [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]] *[[Davy lamp]] – [[Humphry Davy]] *[[Geordie lamp]] – [[George Stephenson]] *[[Beam engine]] – Used for pumping water from mines
==Musical instruments== *[[Concertina]] – [[Charles Wheatstone]]<ref name="bowers_wheatstone"/> *[[Theatre organ]] – [[Robert Hope-Jones]] *[[English horn]] – A version of the [[Oboe]] *Logical [[bassoon]], an electronically controlled version of the [[bassoon]] – [[Giles Brindley]] *[[Northumbrian smallpipes]] *[[Tuning fork]] – [[John Shore (trumpeter)|John Shore]] * The piano footpedal – [[John Broadwood]] (1732–1812) <ref>The wonders of the piano: the anatomy of the instrument Catherine C. Bielefeldt, Alfred R. Weil</ref>
==Photography== *[[Ambrotype]] – [[Frederick Scott Archer]]<ref name="bbc_archer">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/photoblog/2010/04/remembering_frederick_scott_archer.html|title=Remembering Frederick Scott Archer|author=Phil Coomes|publisher=BBC|date=27 April 2010|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> *[[Calotype]] – [[William Fox Talbot]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/fox_talbot_william_henry.shtml|title=BBC – History – Historic Figures: William Henry Fox Talbot (1800–1877)|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> *[[Collodion process]] – Frederick Scott Archer<ref name="bbc_archer"/> *[[Collodion-albumen process]] – Joseph Sidebotham in 1861 *[[Stereoscope]] – [[Charles Wheatstone]]<ref name="kcl_wheatstone">{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/depsta/iss/library/speccoll/wheatstone.html|author=Shelley de Kock|title=Sir Charles Wheatstone and the Wheatstone Collection|accessdate=2010-12-06|publisher=King's College London}}</ref><ref name="bowers_wheatstone"/> *[[Thomas Wedgwood (1771–1805)|Thomas Wedgwood]] – pioneer of photography, devised the method to copy visible images chemically to permanent media. *[[Dry plate]] process also known as gelatine process, is the first economically successful durable photographic medium – [[Richard Leach Maddox]] *[[Kinemacolor]] was the first successful colour [[motion picture]] process, used commercially from 1908 to 1914 – [[George Albert Smith]] *[[Cinematography]] – [[William Friese-Greene]] *Motion picture camera, the [[Kinetoscope]] – [[William Kennedy Laurie Dickson]] *The first [[movie projector]], the [[Zoopraxiscope]] – [[Eadweard Muybridge]] *The first experimental film called "The Horse in Motion" in 1872 – [[Eadweard Muybridge]]
==Publishing firsts== *Oldest publisher and printer in the world (having been operating continuously since 1584): [[Cambridge University Press]] *first book printed in English: "The Recuyell of the Historyes of Troye" by Englishman [[William Caxton]] in 1475 * The first edition of the [[Encyclopædia Britannica]] (1768–81) <ref>Encyclopaedic visions: scientific dictionaries and enlightenment culture By Natasha J. Yeo</ref> * The first English textbook on [[surgery]](1597) <ref>The Early history of surgery William John Bishop – 1995</ref> * The first modern pharmacopaedia, [[William Cullen]] (1776) The book became 'Europe's principal text on the classification and treatment of disease' <ref>http://www.hsl.virginia.edu/historical/rare_books/classics/#Cullen</ref> * The first [[postcard]]s and picture postcards in the UK <ref>Picture Postcards By C W Hill</ref>
==Science== *Modern [[atomic theory]] – Considered the father of modern chemistry, [[John Dalton]]'s experiments with gases led to the development of what is called the modern atomic theory.<ref name="oakes_atoz"/><ref name="windelspecht"/> *[[Equals sign]] [[Robert Recorde]], Welshman *[[Cell biology]] – Credit for the discovery of the first cells is given to [[Robert Hooke]] who described the microscopic compartments of cork cells in 1665<ref name="windelspecht">{{cite book|title=Groundbreaking Scientific Experiments, Inventions, and Discoveries of the 19th Century|author=Windelspecht, Michael|publisher=Greenwood Press|year=2003|isbn=978-0-313-31969-3}}</ref> *Compound [[microscope]] with 30x magnification – [[Robert Hooke]] *[[Universal joint]] – [[Robert Hooke]]{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} *[[Coggeshall slide rule]] – Henry Coggeshall *The [[Iris diaphragm]] – [[Robert Hooke]] *Correct theory of [[combustion]] – [[Robert Hooke]] *Partition [[chromatography]] – [[Richard Laurence Millington Synge]] and [[Archer J.P. Martin]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1952/press.html|title=The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1952|publisher=The Nobel Foundation|accessdate=2010-12-08}}</ref> *[[Arnold Frederic Wilkins]] – pioneer in the development of [[Radar]] *[[Atwood machine]] used for illustrating the law of uniformly accelerated motion – [[George Atwood]] *Marine [[Barometer]] – [[Robert Hooke]]<ref name="dicteng"/> *[[Hooke's Law]] (equation describing elasticity) – [[Robert Hooke]]<ref name="dicteng"/> *[[Electrical generator]] (dynamo) – [[Michael Faraday]]<ref name="rigb_faraday"/> *[[Faraday cage]] – [[Michael Faraday]]<ref name="rigb_faraday"/> *[[Magneto-optical effect]] – [[Michael Faraday]]<ref name="rigb_faraday"/> *[[Calculus]] – [[Sir Isaac Newton]] *[[Infrared#Human history|Infrared]] radiation – discovery commonly attributed to [[William Herschel]]. *[[Holography]] – First developed by [[Dennis Gabor]] in Rugby, England. Improved by [[Nicholas J. Phillips]] who made it possible to record multi-colour reflection holograms *Discovery of the [[pion]] (pi-[[meson]]) – [[Cecil Frank Powell]] *[[Wheatstone bridge]] – [[Samuel Hunter Christie]] *Triple [[achromatic lens]] – [[Peter Dollond]] *[[Newtonian telescope]] – Sir [[Isaac Newton]] *[[Hawking radiation]] – [[Stephen Hawking]] *Demonstrated that [[electric circuit]]s obey the law of the conservation of energy and that [[electricity]] is a form of energy [[First Law of Thermodynamics]]. Also the unit of energy, the [[Joule]] is named after him – [[James Prescott Joule]] *[[Micrometer]] – [[William Gascoigne (scientist)|William Gascoigne]] **the first bench micrometer that was capable of measuring to one ten thousandth of an inch – [[Henry Maudslay]] *[[Sinclair Executive]], the world's first small electronic [[pocket calculator]] – Sir [[Clive Sinclair]] *Discovered the element [[argon]] – [[John Strutt, 3rd Baron Rayleigh]] with Scotsman [[William Ramsay]] *[[Standard deviation]] – [[Francis Galton]] *[[Slide rule]] – [[William Oughtred]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oughtred.org/history-new.shtml |title=The Oughtred Society: Slide Rule History |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070709072617/http://www.oughtred.org/history-new.shtml |archivedate=July 9, 2007 }}</ref> *Synthesis of [[coumarin]], one of the first synthetic [[perfume]]s, and [[cinnamic acid]] via the [[Perkin reaction]] – [[Sir William Henry Perkin|William Henry Perkin]] *The Law of Gravity – Sir [[Isaac Newton]] *[[Newton's laws of motion]] – [[Sir Isaac Newton]] *[[William Kingdon Clifford#Premonition of relativity|Pre-empting elements of General Relativity theory]] – [[William Kingdon Clifford]] *[[Geological Timescale]] – [[Arthur Holmes]]<ref>http://mysite.du.edu/~jcalvert/geol/holmes.htm</ref> *[[Electromagnet]] – [[William Sturgeon]] in 1823.<ref name="windelspecht"/> *[[Helium]] – [[Norman Lockyer]] *[[Weather map]] <ref>[http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/biography/Galton.html Francis Galton (1822–1911) – from Eric Weisstein's World of Scientific Biography<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> – [[Sir Francis Galton]] *Introduced the symbol for "is less than" and "is greater than" – [[Thomas Harriot]] 1630 *Introduced the "×" symbol for [[multiplication]] as well as the abbreviations "sin" and "cos" for the [[sine]] and [[cosine]] functions – [[William Oughtred]] *Dew Point Hygrometer – [[John Frederic Daniell]] *[[Periodic Table]] – [[John Alexander Reina Newlands]] *[[Splitting the atom]] – [[John Cockcroft]] and Irish physicist [[Ernest Walton]] *First full-scale commercial Nuclear Reactor at Calder Hall, opened in 1956.<ref>http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/october/17/newsid_3147000/3147145.stm</ref> *[[Seismograph]] – [[John Milne]] *Discovery of [[oxygen]] gas (O2) – [[Joseph Priestley]] *Discovery of the [[Atom]](nuclear model of) – [[Ernest Rutherford]] *Discovery of the [[Proton]] – [[Ernest Rutherford]] *Discovery of the [[Electron]], [[isotopes]] and the inventor of the [[Mass spectrometer]] – [[J. J. Thomson]] *Discovery of the [[Neutron]] – [[James Chadwick]] *[[Nuclear transfer]] – Is a form of cloning first put into practice by [[Ian Wilmut]] and [[Keith Campbell (biologist)|Keith Campbell]] to clone [[Dolly the Sheep]] *Theory of Evolution – [[Charles Darwin]]

radiation generated by accretion onto a compact object – [[Arthur Stanley Eddington]] <ref>{{cite journal|bibcode=2008AIPC..990..250V|title=Continuum driven winds from super-Eddington stars. A tale of two limits |journal=First Stars Iii |volume=990 |pages=250–253 | doi=10.1063/1.2905555|arxiv = 0708.4207|year=2008 | last1 = van Marle | first1 = A. J.|series=AIP Conference Proceedings }}</ref> *[[Aperture synthesis]], used for accurate location and imaging of weak radio sources in the field of [[Radio astronomy]] – [[Martin Ryle]] and [[Antony Hewish]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nobel-winners.com/Physics/antony_hewish.html|title=Antony Hewish biography}}</ref>
===Chemistry=== *[[Dalton's law]] and [[Law of multiple proportions]] – [[John Dalton]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enotes.com/forensic-science/marsh-james|title=John Dalton, encyclopaedia/hutchinson}}</ref> *The structure of [[DNA]] and pioneering the field of [[molecular biology]] – co-developed by [[Francis Crick]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1962/crick-bio.html|title=Francis Crick's 1962 Biography from the Nobel foundation}}</ref> and the American [[James D. Watson|James Watson]] *[[DNA sequencing]] by chain termination – [[Frederick Sanger]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1958/sanger-bio.html|title=Frederick Sanger}}</ref> *Discovery of [[introns]] in [[eukaryotic]] [[DNA]] and the mechanism of gene-splicing – [[Richard J. Roberts]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1993/roberts-autobio.html |title=Richard J. Roberts Biography from the Nobel foundation}}</ref> *Discovey of [[Buckminsterfullerene]] – [[Sir Harry Kroto]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1996/kroto-autobio.html |title=Harold Kroto – Autobiography from the Nobel foundation}}</ref> *Discovery of [[thallium]] – [[William Crookes]]<ref name="oakes_atoz"/> *Discovered the structure of [[ferrocene]] – [[Geoffrey Wilkinson]] & others <ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1973/wilkinson-autobio.html |title=Geoffrey Wilkinson – Autobiographyfrom the Nobel foundation}}</ref> *Discovers [[hydrogen]] as a colorless, odourless gas that burns and can form an explosive mixture with air – [[Henry Cavendish]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talktalk.co.uk/reference/encyclopaedia/hutchinson/m0000614.html |title=Cavendish, Henry encyclopaedia/hutchinson}}</ref> *Proposes the law of octaves, a precursor to the [[Periodic Law]] – [[John Alexander Reina Newlands|John Newlands]] <ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.bpc.edu/mathscience/chemistry/history_of_the_periodic_table.html |archive-url = https://archive.is/20121214111138/http://www.bpc.edu/mathscience/chemistry/history_of_the_periodic_table.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2012-12-14 |title = History of the Development of the Periodic Table of Elements }}</ref> *[[Bragg's law]] and establish the field of [[X-ray crystallography]], an important tool for elucidating the crystal structure of substances – [[William Henry Bragg]] and [[William Lawrence Bragg]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1915/present.html |title=The Nobel Prize in Physics 1915 William Bragg, Lawrence Bragg}}</ref> *Introduces concept of [[atomic number]] to fix inadequacies of Mendeleev's periodic table, which had been based on atomic weight – [[Henry Moseley]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chemcool.com/biography/moseley.htm |title=Brief biography of Moseley}}</ref> *First isolation of [[sodium]] – [[Humphry Davy]] <ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gpwEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA57#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Davy, Humphry (1808).|author1=Davy, Sir Humphry|year=1840}}</ref> *First isolation of [[potassium]] – [[Humphry Davy]]<ref name="oakes_atoz"/> *First isolation of [[boron]] – [[Humphry Davy]]<ref name="oakes_atoz"/> *First isolation of [[benzene]], the first known [[aromatic hydrocarbon]] – [[Michael Faraday]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rigb.org/contentControl?action=displayContent&id=00000001043|title=Michael Faraday for beginners|publisher=The Royal Institution of Great Britain|accessdate=2010-12-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101223060736/http://www.rigb.org/contentControl?action=displayContent&id=00000001043|archivedate=2010-12-23|df=}}</ref> *Publishes Opus Maius, which among other things, proposes an early form of the [[scientific method]], and contains results of his experiments with [[gunpowder]] – [[Roger Bacon]] <ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ru_E__W7euUC&pg=PA39&dq=roger-bacon+scientific-method#v=onepage&q=roger-bacon%20scientific-method&f=false |title=Introduction to Forensic Engineering|isbn=978-0-8493-8102-7|author1=Noon, Randall|year=1992}}</ref> *Publishes several Aristotelian commentaries, an early framework for the [[scientific method]] – [[Robert Grosseteste]] <ref>{{Cite journal|title=A. C. Crombie, Robert Grosseteste and the Origins of Experimental Science, 1100–1700, (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1971), pp. 52-60.|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> *[[Baconian method]], an early forerunner of the [[scientific method]] – [[Sir Francis Bacon]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/48191/Baconian-method|title=Baconian method|work=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> *The first discovery of [[aluminium]] – Sir [[Humphry Davy]] *Pioneer in early Solar Power – [[Weston cell]] – [[Edward Weston (chemist)]]{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} *Proposes the concept of [[isotopes]], elements with the same chemical properties may have differing atomic weights – [[Frederick Soddy]]<ref name="oakes_atoz"/> *The synthesising of [[xenon hexafluoroplatinate]] the first time to show that noble gases can form chemical compounds – [[Neil Bartlett (chemist)|Neil Bartlett]] *[[Callendar effect]] the theory that linked rising carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere to global temperature ([[Global warming]]) – [[Guy Stewart Callendar]] *Pioneer of the [[fuel cell]] – [[Francis Thomas Bacon]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.todaysengineer.org/2005/Mar/history.asp|title=Francis Thomas Bacon and the Fuel Cell|author=Matthew Eisler|publisher=IEEE-USA}}</ref> *Pioneer of [[meteorology]] by developing a nomenclature system for [[clouds]] in 1802 – [[Luke Howard]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rmets.org/weather/observing/luke-howard.php|title=Luke Howard and Cloud Names|publisher=Royal Meteorological Society|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> *[[Rayleigh scattering]] explains why the sky is blue, and predicted the existence of the [[surface waves]] – [[John Strutt, 3rd Baron Rayleigh]]<ref name=prixnobel>{{cite web | year=1904| title=Lord Rayleigh: The Nobel Prize in Physics 1904| url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1904/strutt-bio.html| publisher=[[The Nobel Foundation]]| accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref>
==Sport== *[[Association football|Football]] – The rules as we know them today were established in 1848 at [[Cambridge University]], [[Sheffield F.C.]] is acknowledged by [[The Football Association]] and [[FIFA]] as the world's first and oldest football club.<ref>Encyclopedia of British Football by Richard Cox et al., Routledge, 2002 page 5</ref> *[[Rugby football|Rugby]] – [[William Webb Ellis]] *[[Cricket]] – the world's second-most popular sport can be traced back to the 13th century<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140053/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1300.html From Lads to Lord's: 1300–1600]</ref> *[[Tennis]] – widely known to have originated in England.<ref>[http://www.historyoftennis.net/history_of_tennis.html The History of Tennis<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723143635/http://www.historyoftennis.net/history_of_tennis.html |date=2011-07-23 }}</ref> *[[Boxing]] – England played a key role in the evolution of modern boxing. Boxing was first accepted as an Olympic sport in Ancient Greece in 688 BC * [[Golf]] – Modern game invented in Scotland * [[Billiards]] * [[Badminton]] *[[Darts]] – a traditional pub game, the numbering layout was devised by Brian Gamlin *[[Table-Tennis]] – was invented on the dinner tables of Britain as an indoor version of tennis *[[Snooker]] – Invented by the British Army in India<ref>http://www.snookerclub.com/snooker.shtml</ref> *[[Ping pong]] – The game has its origins in England, in the 1880s *[[Bowls]] – has been traced to 13th century England<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/h2g2/A311482</ref> *[[Field hockey]] – the modern game grew from English public schools in the early 19th century *[[Netball]] – the sport emerged from early versions of women's basketball, at [[Martina Bergman-Österberg|Madame Österberg]]'s College in England during the late 1890s.<ref>{{cite web|author=International Federation of Netball Associations |title=History of Netball |url=http://www.netball.org/Netball.aspx?id=18 |accessdate=2008-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110306141537/http://www.netball.org/Netball.aspx?id=18 |archivedate=2011-03-06 |df= }}</ref> *[[Rounders]] – the game originates in England most likely from an older game known as [[stool ball]] *The [[Oxford]] and [[Cambridge]] [[The Boat Race|Boat Race]], the first race was in 1829 on the River [[Thames]] in [[London]] <ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/3546387.stm | work=BBC News | title=Past Boat Race winners | date=2005-03-07 | accessdate=2010-05-02}}</ref> *[[Thoroughbred]] Horseracing – Was first developed in 17th and 18th century England *[[Polo]] – its roots began in Persia as a training game for cavalry units, the formal codification of the rules of modern Polo as a sport were established in 19th century England *The format of Modern [[Olympics]] – [[William Penny Brookes]] * The first [[Paralympic games]] competition were held in England in 1948 – [[Ludwig Guttmann]]<ref>[http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0009617 Paralympic Games – The Canadian Encyclopedia<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *[[Hawk-Eye]] ball tracking system.
==Transport==
===Aviation=== *[[Aeronautics]] and flight. As a pioneer of [[glider aircraft|glider]] development & first well-documented human flight he discovered and identified the four aerodynamic forces of flight – [[weight]], [[Lift (soaring)|lift]], [[Drag (physics)|drag]], and [[thrust]]. Modern airplane design is based on those discoveries including [[Camber (aerodynamics)|cambered wings]]. He is sometimes called the "Father of [[aviation]]" – [[George Cayley]]<ref name="wired_cayley">{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2003/12/61611|title=The Englishman Who Wanted to Fly|date=2003-12-16|author=Noah Shachtman|work=Wired Magazine|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> *Steam-powered flight with the [[Aerial Steam Carriage]] – [[John Stringfellow]] – The world's first powered flight took place at Chard in Somerset 55 years before the Wright brothers attempt at Kitty Hawk<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/1591057.stm|title=High hopes for replica plane|date=10 October 2001|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> *[[VTOL]] (vertical take-off and landing) fighter-bomber aircraft – [[Hawker P.1127]], designed by [[Sydney Camm]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/6841130/Campaign-to-honour-Hawker-Hurricane-designer-Sir-Sydney-Camm.html|title=Campaign to honour Hawker Hurricane designer Sir Sydney Camm|date=26 Dec 2009|author=Gordon Rayner|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=2010-12-06|location=London}}</ref> *The first commercial [[jet airliner]] ([[de Havilland Comet]])<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/2/newsid_2480000/2480339.stm|title=1952: Comet inaugurates the jet age|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2010-12-06|date=1952-05-02}}</ref> *The first [[Supersonic airliner|Supersonic Airliner]] – [[Concorde]]. Developed by the [[British Aircraft Corporation]] in partnership with [[Aérospatiale]] 1969 *The first aircraft capable of [[supercruise]] – [[English Electric Lightning]] *[[Ailerons]] – [[Matthew Piers Watt Boulton]] *[[Head-up display]] (HUD) – The [[Royal Aircraft Establishment]] (RAE) designed the first equipment and it was built by Cintel with the system first integrated into the [[Blackburn Buccaneer]]. *Pioneer of [[parachute]] design – [[Robert Cocking]] * The first [[human-powered aircraft]] to make an officially authenticated take-off and flight ([[Southampton University Man Powered Aircraft|SUMPAC]]) – [[The University of Southampton]]<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-15705954</ref> *Hale [[rocket]]s, improved version of the [[Congreve rocket]] design that introduced [[Thrust vectoring]] – [[William Hale (British inventor)|William Hale]] *[[SABRE (rocket engine)|SABRE]] engine- The first hypersonic jet/rocket capable of working in air and space to allow the possibility of [[HOTOL]]. *[[Air force|Air Force]] – [[Royal Air Force]]
===Railways=== * [[Great Western Railway]] – [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]] * [[Stockton and Darlington Railway]] the world's first operational steam passenger railway * First inter-city steam-powered railway – [[Liverpool and Manchester Railway]]
====Locomotives==== *''[[Blücher (locomotive)|Blücher]]'' – [[George Stephenson]] *''[[Puffing Billy (locomotive)|Puffing Billy]]'' -[[William Hedley]] *''[[Locomotion No 1]]'' – [[Robert Stephenson]] *''[[Sans Pareil]]'' – [[Timothy Hackworth]] *''[[Stourbridge Lion]]'' – [[Foster, Rastrick and Company]] *''[[Stephenson's Rocket]]'' – [[George Stephenson|George]] and [[Robert Stephenson]] *''[[Salamanca (locomotive)|Salamanca]]'' – [[Matthew Murray]] *''[[LNER Class A3 4472 Flying Scotsman|Flying Scotsman]]''- [[Sir Nigel Gresley]] <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-lancashire-37666738 |title=Plaque for railway pioneer Sir Nigel Gresley |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2017-10-28 }}</ref>
====Other railway developments==== *[[Displacement lubricator]], Ramsbottom [[safety valve]], the [[water trough]], the split [[piston ring]] – [[John Ramsbottom (engineer)|John Ramsbottom]] * [[Maglev (transport)]] rail system – [[Eric Laithwaite]] * World's first underground railway and the first [[rapid transit]] system. It was also the first underground railway to operate electric trains – [[London Underground]] *[[Advanced Passenger Train]] (APT) was an experimental High Speed Train that introduced [[tilting train|tilting]] – [[British Rail]]
===Roads=== *[[Bowden cable]] – Frank Bowden *[[Hansom cab]] – [[Joseph Hansom]] *[[Seat belt]] – [[George Cayley]]<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/features/Clunk-click--an-invention.5583475.jp?articlepage=1|title=Clunk, click – an invention that's saved lives for 50 years|author=Manby, Frederic|date=24 August 2009|accessdate=2010-12-04|publisher=Johnston Press Digital Publishing|newspaper=Yorkshire Post}}</ref> *[[Sinclair C5]] – Sir [[Clive Sinclair]] *[[Tarmacadam|Tarmac]] – [[E. Purnell Hooley]] *Tension-spoke [[wire wheels]] – [[George Cayley]]<ref name="wired_cayley"/> *[[LGOC B-type]] – the first mass-produced bus *[[Tire|Pneumatic tyre]] – [[Robert William Thomson]] is deemed to be inventor, despite [[John Boyd Dunlop]] being initially credited *[[Disc brake]]s – [[Frederick W. Lanchester]]<ref name="oakes_atoz"/> *[[Belisha beacon]] – [[Leslie Hore-Belisha]] *[[Lotus 25]]: considered the first modern F1 race car, designed for the 1962 [[Formula One]] season; a revolutionary design, the first fully stressed [[monocoque]] chassis to appear in Formula One – [[Colin Chapman]], [[Team Lotus]] *[[Horstmann suspension]], tracked armoured fighting vehicle suspension – [[Sidney Horstmann]] *Steam [[fire engine]] – [[John Braithwaite (engineer)|John Braithwaite]] *[[Penny-farthing]] – [[James Starley]] *[[Dynasphere]] – [[John Archibald Purves]] *[[Continuous track|Caterpillar track]] – [[Richard Lovell Edgeworth]] *[[Mini-roundabout]] – [[Frank Blackmore]] *[[Quadbike]] – [[Standard Motor Company]] patented the 'Jungle Airborne Buggy' (JAB) in 1944<ref>http://4x4channel.tv/1944-the-first-quad-bike-sxs-built-in-britain</ref>
===Sea=== *[[Plimsoll Line]] – [[Samuel Plimsoll]] *[[Hovercraft]] – [[Christopher Cockerell]] *[[Lifeboat (rescue)|Lifeboat]] – [[Lionel Lukin]] *[[Resurgam]] – [[George Garrett (inventor)|George Garrett]] *[[Transit (ship)]] – [[Richard Hall Gower]] *[[Turbinia]], the first [[steam turbine]] powered [[steamship]], designed by the engineer Sir [[Charles Algernon Parsons]] and built in [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] *Diving Equipment/Scuba Gear – [[Henry Fleuss]] *[[Diving bell]] – [[Edmund Halley]] *[[Sextant]] – [[John Bird (astronomer)|John Bird]] *[[Octant (instrument)]] – Independently developed by Englishman [[John Hadley]] and the American [[Thomas Godfrey (inventor)|Thomas Godfrey]] *Whirling speculum, This device can be seen as a precursor to the [[gyroscope]] – [[John Serson]] *[[Screw propeller]] – [[Francis Pettit Smith]] *The world's first patent for an underwater echo ranging device ([[Sonar]]) – [[Lewis Richardson]] *[[hydrophone]] Before the invention of [[Sonar]] convoy escort ships used them to detect U-boats, greatly lessening the effectiveness of the [[submarine]] – Research headed by [[Ernest Rutherford]] *[[Hydrofoil]] – [[John Isaac Thornycroft]] *[[Inflatable boat]] *{{HMS|Warrior|1860|6}} The world's first iron armoured and iron hulled warship.
==Scientific innovations== * The theory of [[electromagnetism]] – [[James Clerk Maxwell]] (1831–1879) <ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/370621/James-Clerk-Maxwell Encyclopædia Britannica – James Clerk Maxwell]</ref> * The [[Gregorian telescope]] – [[James Gregory (astronomer and mathematician)|James Gregory]] (1638–1675) <ref>Popular Astronomy By Simon Newcomb</ref> * The concept of [[latent heat]] – [[Joseph Black]] (1728–1799) <ref>Logic, language, information and computation: 15th international workshop, WoLLIC 2008, Edinburgh, UK, July 1–4, 2008</ref> * The pyroscope, [[atmometer]] and [[aethrioscope]] scientific instruments: Sir [[John Leslie (physicist)|John Leslie]] (1766–1832) <ref>Chambers's encyclopaedia: a dictionary of universal knowledge for the people Appleton 1864</ref> * Identifying the [[cell nucleus|nucleus]] in living [[cell (biology)|cells]] – [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|Robert Brown]] (1773–1858) <ref>Biology: Concepts and Applications Without Physiology By Cecie Starr, Christine A. Evers, Lisa Starr</ref> * [[Hypnotism]] – [[James Braid (surgeon)|James Braid]] (1795–1860) <ref>The Discovery of Hypnosis- The Complete Writings of James Braid, the Father of Hypnotherapy James Braid, Donald Robertson (ed.) 2009</ref> * [[Transplant rejection]]: Professor Thomas Gibson (1940s) the first medical doctor to understand the relationship between donor graft tissue and host tissue rejection and tissue transplantation by his work on aviation burns victims during [[World War II]].<ref>http://www.worldchanging.glasgow.ac.uk/article/?id=53</ref> * [[Colloid chemistry]] – [[Thomas Graham (chemist)|Thomas Graham]] (1805–1869) <ref>Colloid chemistry Robert James Hartman, Herman Thompson Briscoe Houghton Mifflin Co., 1947</ref> * The [[kelvin]] [[SI]] [[Units of measurement|unit]] of [[temperature]] – [[William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin|William Thomson]], Lord Kelvin (1824–1907) <ref>Chemistry and chemical reactivity, Volume 2 By John C. Kotz, Paul Treichel, John Raymond Townsend</ref> * Devising the diagramatic system of representing [[chemical bonds]] – [[Alexander Crum Brown]] (1838–1922) <ref>Scottish pride: 101 reasons to be proud of your Scottish heritage Heather Duncan</ref> * Criminal [[fingerprint]]ing – [[Henry Faulds]] (1843–1930) <ref>Criminalistics: Forensic Science and Crime By James Girard</ref> * The [[noble gas]]es: Sir [[William Ramsay]] (1852–1916) <ref>Noble Gases By Jens Thomas</ref> * The [[Cloud chamber]] – [[Charles Thomson Rees Wilson]] (1869–1959) <ref>The world of the atom Henry Abraham Boorse, Lloyd Motz Basic Books, inc., 1966</ref> * Pioneering work on [[nutrition]] and [[poverty]] – [[John Boyd Orr]] (1880–1971) <ref>[http://cache.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/76466/John-Boyd-Orr-Baron-Boyd-Orr-of-Brechin-Mearns Encyclopædia Britannica: Lord Boyd Orr]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * The [[ultrasound scanner]] – [[Ian Donald]] (1910–1987) <ref>Ian Donald's Practical Obstetric Problem, 6/e By Renu Misra</ref> * [[Ferrocene]] synthetic substances – Peter Ludwig Pauson in 1955 <ref>Journal of the Chemical Society Chemical Society (Great Britain), Bureau of Chemical Abstracts (Great Britain) The Society, 1920</ref> * The [[MRI body scanner]] – [[John Mallard]] and James Huchinson from (1974–1980) <ref>A history of neurosurgery: in its scientific and professional contexts By Samuel H. Greenblatt, T. Forcht Dagi</ref> * The first [[Cloning|cloned]] mammal ([[Dolly the Sheep]]): Was conducted in The [[Roslin Institute]] research centre in 1996 <ref>From Sea Urchins to Dolly the Sheep: Discovering Cloning Sally Morgan Heinemann/Raintree, 2007</ref> * [[Seismometer]] innovations thereof – [[James David Forbes]] <ref>Transactions of the Royal Scottish Society of Arts Royal Scottish Society of Arts Neill & Co., 1883</ref> * [[Metamaterials|Metaflex]] fabric innovations thereof – [[University of St. Andrews]] (2010) application of the first manufacturing fabrics that manipulate light in bending it around a subject. Before this such light manipulating atoms were fixed on flat hard surfaces. The team at St Andrews are the first to develop the concept to fabric.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.stv.tv/internet-technology/206620-scientists-reveal-material-for-invisibility-cloak/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-09-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160516003958/http://news.stv.tv/internet-technology/206620-scientists-reveal-material-for-invisibility-cloak/ |archivedate=2016-05-16 |df= }}</ref> * [[Macaulayite]]: Dr Jeff Wilson of the [[Macaulay Institute]], [[Aberdeen]].<ref>A Handbook of determinative methods in clay mineralogy Michael Jeffrey Wilson, Michael John Wilson Blackie, 1987</ref>

"Boys' Brigade want alumni to return for a special anniversary". Retrieved 2008-10-30.</ref> *[[Bank of England]] devised by [[William Paterson (banker)|William Paterson]] *[[Bank of France]] devised by [[John Law (economist)|John Law]] *[[Colour photography]]: the first known permanent colour photograph was taken by [[James Clerk Maxwell]] (1831–1879) <ref>The Focal encyclopedia of photography By Leslie Stroebel, Richard D. Zakia</ref> * [[Barnardos]] * [[Boy Scouts]] * [[Girl Guides]] * [[RSPCA]] * [[RSPB]] * [[RNLI]]
