[[File:18thSD (6009531142).jpg|thumb|An example of door-to-door canvassing, the topic of the ''When contact changes minds'' paper.]] '''"When contact changes minds: An experiment on transmission of support for gay equality"''' is an article by then-[[UCLA]] [[political science]] [[graduate student]] Michael LaCour and [[Columbia University]] political science professor [[Donald Green]]. The article was published in the academic journal ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' in December 2014, and [[retraction|retracted]] in May 2015 after it emerged that the data in the study had been forged by LaCour.<ref name="WapoGelman"/> The article purported to demonstrate that people's minds on the issue of [[gay marriage]] could be changed by conversations with gay [[Canvassing|canvassers]], but not with straight canvassers.
== Study == The authors investigated whether gay or straight messengers were effective at encouraging voters to support same-sex marriage and whether attitude change persisted and spread to others in voters’ social networks. The results, measured by an unrelated panel survey, show that both gay and straight canvassers produced large effects initially, but only gay canvassers’ effects persisted in 3-week, 6-week, and 9-month follow-ups. LaCour and Green (2014) also found strong evidence of within-household transmission of opinion change, but only in the wake of conversations with gay canvassers.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = LaCour | first1 = Michael J. | last2 = Green | first2 = Donald P. | year = 2014 | title = When contact changes minds: An experiment on transmission of support for gay equality|url=https://www.dropbox.com/s/qcd5b6urfluqso5/Science-2014-LaCour-Green.pdf?dl=0 |format=PDF | journal = Science | volume = 346 | issue = 6215| page = 1366 | doi=10.1126/science.1256151 | pmid=25504721}}</ref>
The article has been downloaded over 111,000 times and ranks in the top 5% of all research output, as scored using [[Altmetrics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/articleusage?gca=sci;346/6215/1366|title=When contact changes minds: An experiment on transmission of support for gay equality|publisher=Science|work=Science Article Usage Statistics Center}}</ref>
The study's findings made international headlines and received wide media attention including in ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/12/health/gay-marriage-canvassing-study-science.html | title=Gay advocates can shift same-sex marriage views | journal=[[New York Times]] | date=11 December 2014 | accessdate=31 May 2015 | author=Carey, Benedict}}</ref> ''[[The Washington Post]]'',<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2014/12/11/one-conversation-can-change-minds-on-same-sex-marriage-study-finds/ | title=One conversation can change minds on same-sex marriage, study finds | department=Post Nation | journal=[[The Washington Post]] | date=11 December 2014 | accessdate=31 May 2015 | author=Somashekhar, Sandhya}}</ref> ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'',<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/gay-marriage-how-to-change-minds-1424882037 | title=Gay marriage: How to change minds |department=Mind and Matter| journal=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=25 February 2015 | accessdate=31 May 2015 | author=[[Sapolsky, Robert M.]]}}</ref> ''[[The Economist]]'', ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'', and ''[[This American Life]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/555/the-incredible-rarity-of-changing-your-mind | title=The incredible rarity of changing your mind | journal=[[This American Life]]|date=25 April 2015 | accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref> The study attracted widespread attention, in part, because it seemed to challenge the conventional wisdom and scholarship about [[persuasion|social persuasion]] that suggests that people tend to maintain their points of view, sometimes regardless of what they read or hear to the contrary.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/05/20/co-author-disavows-highly-publicized-study-on-public-opinion-and-same-sex-marriage/ | title=Co-author disavows highly publicized study on public opinion and same-sex marriage | department = Morning Mix | journal=[[The Washington Post]] | date=20 May 2015 | accessdate=2 June 2015 | author=Barbash, Fred}}</ref>
The Yes Campaign in Ireland stated that LaCour and Green (2014) “provided a template" for campaigners to use one-to-one contact and first person accounts to reach out to more conservative voters, leading to the historic [[Irish referendum legalizing gay marriage]] on May 22, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/personal-route-to-reach-public-central-to-yes-campaign-1.2211282|title=Personal route to reach public central to Yes campaign|date=14 May 2015|work=[[The Irish Times]]}}</ref>
==Falsified data== The ''When contact changes minds'' study was subsequently discredited after a critique by David Broockman, Joshua Kalla, and Peter Aronow on May 19, 2015, titled "Irregularities in LaCour (2014)",<ref name="irregularities">{{cite web | url=http://stanford.edu/~dbroock/broockman_kalla_aronow_lg_irregularities.pdf | title=Irregularities in LaCour (2014) | date=19 May 2015 | accessdate=30 May 2015 | author=Broockman, David, Kalla, Joshua, and Aronow, Peter}}</ref> that concluded that the data had been falsified and no data had actually ever been collected. Broockman et al. found that the survey company LaCour claimed to have used denied performing any work for LaCour and did not have an employee by the name LaCour listed as his contact with the company.<ref name="irregularities" /> In addition, LaCour had claimed that participants were paid using outside funding, but no organization could be found that had provided the large amount of money required to pay thousands of people.
The "Irregularities" paper also identified the likely method by which LaCour had forged the data. The baseline survey results appeared to have been taken from an earlier dataset called the [[Cooperative Campaign Analysis Project]] (CCAP), to which LaCour had access. The later sets of data appeared to have been simulated from the first using statistical methods to shift the results and by adding [[normal distribution|normally distributed]] [[Noise (signal processing)|noise]].<ref name="irregularities" /><ref name="The Problem With Michael LaCour’s Rebuttal">{{cite web|title=Neuroskeptic blog – The Problem With Michael LaCour’s Rebuttal|url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/2015/06/01/problem-michael-lacours-rebuttal/|website = [[Discover Magazine]]|accessdate=8 April 2016}}</ref> In addition, the paper noted that canvasser identifiers were missing from the results, making it impossible to verify whether different canvassers produced different results as the original study claimed.
Additional evidence of the study's fictitiousness later emerged, such as evidence that LaCour had tried to retroactively claim that the study had been pre-registered using falsified documents.<ref name="Michael LaCour Probably Fabricated a Document About Research Integrity">{{cite web|last1=Singal|first1=Jesse|title=Michael LaCour Probably Fabricated a Document About Research Integrity|url=http://nymag.com/scienceofus/2015/06/lacour-probably-fabricated-an-integrity-document.html|website=Science of Us|publisher=[[NY Magazine]]|accessdate=8 April 2016}}</ref>
LaCour's coauthor, [[Donald Green]], subsequently requested that the paper be retracted because of “irregularities” in the paper's data and LaCour's failure to give him the [[raw data]] on which the paper was based.<ref>{{citation|title=Co-author disavows highly publicized study on public opinion and same-sex marriage|department=Morning Mix|journal=[[Washington Post]]|first=Fred|last=Barbash|date=May 20, 2015|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/05/20/co-author-disavows-highly-publicized-study-on-public-opinion-and-same-sex-marriage/}}</ref> Yet Green, as senior author on the ''Science'' paper, certified that he had examined the raw/original data on his ''Science''/AAAS Authorship Form and Statement of Conflicts of Interest.<ref>https://www.sciencemag.org/site/feature/contribinfo/prep/coi.pdf</ref> The ''Science'' terms include, prominently, the following statement: “The senior author from each group is required to have examined the raw data their group has produced.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://retractionwatch.com/2015/06/18/if-you-think-its-rude-to-ask-to-look-at-your-co-authors-data-youre-not-doing-science-guest-post/|title="If you think it’s rude to ask to look at your co-authors’ data, you’re not doing science": Guest post|work=[[Retraction Watch]]}}</ref>
In his letter to the journal, Green wrote: "I am deeply embarrassed by this turn of events and apologize to the editors, reviewers, and readers of ''Science''."<ref name="CBSNews">{{cite web |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/science-journal-retracts-controversial-lacour-gay-marriage-study/ |title=Journal retracts controversial gay marriage study |last1=Schupak |first1=Amanda |date=May 29, 2015 |publisher=[[CBS News]] |access-date=June 7, 2015 |quote="But after two researchers raised serious questions about a lack of data and funding details outlined in the study, Green wrote to Science asking that it be retracted. "Michael LaCour's failure to produce the raw data coupled with the other concerns noted above undermines the credibility of the findings," he wrote. "I am deeply embarrassed by this turn of events and apologize to the editors, reviewers, and readers of Science."}}</ref> [[Andrew Gelman]], a professor of statistics and political science at [[Columbia University]], wrote in the ''Washington Post'' that Donald Green had accepted LaCour's data "on faith".<ref name="WapoGelman">{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/monkey-cage/wp/2015/05/20/fake-study-on-changing-attitudes-sometimes-a-claim-that-is-too-good-to-be-true-isnt/ |title=Fake study on changing attitudes: Sometimes a claim that is too good to be true, isn’t |last1=Gelman |first1=Andrew |date=May 20, 2015 |website=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=June 7, 2015 |quote="Not to spoil the suspense or anything, but what really happened was that the data were faked by first author LaCour. Co-author Green (my colleague at Columbia) had taken his collaborator’s data on faith; once he found out, he firmly retracted the article. Details at Retraction Watch."}}</ref> On May 28, 2015, the study was retracted by ''Science'',<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/29/science/journal-science-retracts-study-on-gay-canvassers-and-same-sex-marriage.html | title=Journal retracts study on changing attitudes on same-sex marriage | work=[[New York Times]] | date=28 May 2015 | accessdate=28 May 2015 | author=Carey, Benedict}}</ref> on the basis that incentives to participate in the survey on which the study was based had been misrepresented, that sponsors had been falsely identified, that the authors could not produce the original data, and (citing the findings of Broockman et al.) that there were "statistical irregularities."<ref name=retract>{{cite journal|last1=McNutt|first1=M.|title=Editorial retraction|journal=Science|date=28 May 2015|volume=348|issue=6239|page=1100|doi=10.1126/science.aac6638|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/348/6239/1100.2.full}}</ref>
On May 29, 2015, LaCour uploaded a response to the criticisms.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://retractionwatch.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/LaCour_Response_05-29-2015.pdf | title=Journal retracts response to irregularities in LaCour and Green (2014) | date=29 May 2015 | accessdate=30 May 2015 | author=LaCour, Michael}}</ref> LaCour admitted to some false statements and apologized for "misrepresenting survey incentives and funding," but denied intentionally falsifying the data itself (though he stated that he could not rule out the possibility that he had "mistakenly mixed up" hypothetical data with collected data). He disputed the timeline of events presented in Broockman et al. (2015). He argued that the failure of Broockman et al. to replicate LaCour and Green (2014) was likely the result of a failure to follow the respondent-driven sampling procedure used in LaCour and Green (2014). He stated that Broockman et al. had selected the "incorrect variable" from CCAP (2012) and then manipulated that variable to make the distribution look more like that in LaCour and Green (2014). LaCour claimed that when the "correct" variable is used, the distributions between the CCAP thermometer and the LaCour and Green (2014) thermometer are statistically distinguishable. LaCour said, "selecting the incorrect variable may have been an oversight, but further manipulating that variable to make the distribution look more like LaCour and Green (2014) is a curious and possibly intentional 'error.'" LaCour also claimed that an independent replication supported the main finding reported in LaCour and Green (2014).
In the ''New York Times'' article, LaCour said the study erred in methods, not results.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/30/science/michael-lacour-gay-marriage-science-study-retraction.html | title=Study using gay canvassers erred in methods, not results, author says |work=The New York Times| date=29 May 2015 | accessdate=31 May 2015 | author=Carey, Benedict}}</ref> A subsequent article published by ''Science'' indicated that LaCour's response was lacking, failing to address a number of issues while raising new questions about his conduct.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://news.sciencemag.org/scientific-community/2015/05/gay-marriage-study-author-lacour-issues-defense-critics-arent-budging |title=Gay marriage study author LaCour issues defense, but critics aren't budging |last1=Malakoff |first1=David |date=May 30, 2015 |website=news.sciencemag.org/ |publisher=Science |access-date=June 9, 2015 |quote="LaCour’s response does not, however, directly answer a number of other questions surrounding the study—and it raises new issues."}}</ref> A blog post published by ''Discover'' stated that LaCour's rebuttal arguments were "very weak" and failed to refute a central criticism of the Broockman paper.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/2015/06/01/problem-michael-lacours-rebuttal/ |title=The Problem With Michael LaCour’s Rebuttal |last1=Neuroskeptic |date=June 1, 2015 |website=blogs.discovermagazine.com |publisher=Discover |access-date=June 9, 2015}}</ref>
After the retraction, the [[Carnegie Corporation of New York]] rescinded Donald Green's 2015 [[Andrew Carnegie Fellowship]], revoking a $200,000 award to support Donald Green's research,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://carnegie.org/news/grantee-news/andrew-carnegie-fellows-2015/|title=Andrew Carnegie Fellows 2015|work=Carnegie Corporation of New York}}</ref> and Princeton University rescinded an assistant professorship that had been offered to LaCour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailyprincetonian.com/news/2015/06/u-revokes-hire-offer-after-allegations-of-publishing-falsified-data/|title=U. revokes hire offer after allegations of publishing falsified data|work=[[Daily Princetonian]]|access-date=2015-07-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150703010814/http://dailyprincetonian.com/news/2015/06/u-revokes-hire-offer-after-allegations-of-publishing-falsified-data/#|archive-date=2015-07-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
The journal ''Science'' retracted the article with the concurrence of Green while LaCour did not agree to the retraction.<ref name=retract/>
== Popular press == While Green, David Broockman, and Joshua Kalla conducted numerous interviews with reporters outlining their version of events, LaCour refrained from talking to the media with the exception of a single interview with ''The New York Times''.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Study Using Gay Canvassers Erred in Methods, Not Results, Author Says|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/30/science/michael-lacour-gay-marriage-science-study-retraction.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-05-29|access-date = 2015-11-19|issn = 0362-4331|first = Benedict|last = Carey}}</ref> Various opinions were advanced in the popular media regarding the implications of the scandal and the motivations of the parties involved.<ref name=WSJ /><ref name="Guardian">Gambino, Lauren and Devlin, Hannah. [https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/may/20/same-sex-marriage-attitudes-study-retracted-fake-data "Study of attitudes to same-sex marriage retracted over 'fake data'"], [[The Guardian]] (May 20, 2015).</ref><ref name="NYM2">Foster, Drew. [http://nymag.com/scienceofus/2015/06/will-academia-waste-the-michael-lacour-scandal.html "Will Academia Waste the Michael LaCour Scandal?"], [[New York Magazine]] (June 5, 2015).</ref><ref name=Seattle />
The editorial page of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' speculated that LaCour's argument originally gained acceptance in the scientific community because it "flattered the ideological sensibilities of [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberals]], who tend to believe that resistance to gay marriage can only be the artifact of ignorance or prejudice, not moral or religious conviction. Mr. LaCour's findings let them claim that science had proved them right." The ''Journal'' editorial further argued that the paper and its acceptance reflected a broader phenomenon in the social sciences in which liberals, according to the editorial, "recast stubborn political debates about philosophy and values as disputes over facts that can be resolved by science".<ref name="WSJ">{{cite news |author=<!--Staff editorial writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Scientific Fraud and Politics |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/scientific-fraud-and-politics-1433544688 |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |location=New York, NY |date=June 6, 2015}}</ref> ''[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]'' columnist Jesse Singal dismissed the ''Wall Street Journal'' editorial, arguing that it was silly and uninformed, and suggested instead that the main reason for the article's publication was its contradiction of prior research.<ref name="NYM1">Singal, Jesse. [http://nymag.com/scienceofus/2015/06/social-science-a-giant-liberal-conspiracy.html "Is Social Science a Giant Liberal Conspiracy?"], [[New York Magazine]] (June 8, 2015).</ref> Gelman, referring to LaCour's study, said that the journal ''Science'' is sometimes called a tabloid "because of its pattern of publishing dramatic but fishy claims (at least in social science)".<ref name="WapoGelman" /> He added that one reason LaCour's fabrications were able to go unnoticed for so long was that they were so all-encompassing and thus could not be detected by normal statistical checks.<ref name="WapoGelman" /> Conservative pro-gay-marriage columnist [[S.E. Cupp]] wrote that, "The doctored study will only encourage the perception that advocates are going too far."<ref name=Seattle>Cupp, S.E. [http://www.seattletimes.com/opinion/key-to-changing-hearts-and-minds-on-gay-marriage-dont-lie-or-bully/ "Key to changing hearts and minds on gay marriage: Don’t lie or bully; As a supporter of gay marriage, I can attest that too often other supporters go too far."], [[Seattle Times]] (May 25, 2014).</ref>
As to what motivated LaCour's behavior in the first place, his co-author, Donald Green, has expressed bafflement.<ref name="Guardian" /> ''New York Magazine'' points to the pressure that social scientists are under to publish scholarly articles, while stating that "profound pressure to publish certainly can’t explain LaCour’s deception on its own".<ref name="NYM2" /> A ''New York'' magazine opinion piece by sociology doctoral candidate Drew Foster argued that the study exposed problems with the culture of political science research and supervision given to junior academics, along with a competitive culture caused by overproduction of PhD students relative to available political science academic positions.<ref name="Will Academia Waste the Michael LaCour Scandal?">{{cite web|last1=Foster|first1=Drew|title=Will Academia Waste the Michael LaCour Scandal?|url=http://nymag.com/scienceofus/2015/06/will-academia-waste-the-michael-lacour-scandal.html|website=Science of Us – New York magazine|accessdate=8 April 2016}}</ref>
== Follow-up study ==
Following their debunking of ''When Contact Changes Minds'', Broockman and Kalla (2016) conducted an experiment similar to the one purported to have been conducted by LaCour and Green.<ref name="No, Wait">{{cite news|title=No, Wait, Short Conversations Really Can Reduce Prejudice|author=[[Ed Yong]]|newspaper=The Atlantic|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2016/04/no-wait-short-conversations-really-can-reduce-prejudice/477105/|date=7 April 2016|accessdate=8 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bohannon |first1=John |title=For real this time: Talking to people about gay and transgender issues can change their prejudices |journal=Science |date=7 April 2016 |doi=10.1126/science.aaf9890}} {{open access}}</ref> Households in Florida were sent a survey on social attitudes, and were later visited by canvassers to discuss either recycling or [[transphobia]] and [[transgender rights]], with the change in the householders' opinions tracked by follow-up surveys. The study found that extended conversations with canvassers did in fact reduce anti-transgender prejudice and were more effective long-term than [[attack ad]]s.<ref name="Durably reducing transphobia">{{cite journal|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/352/6282/220|title=Durably reducing transphobia: A field experiment on door-to-door canvassing|first1=David|last1=Broockman|first2=Joshua|last2=Kalla|doi=10.1126/science.aad9713 |date=28 April 2016|journal=Science|volume=352|issue=6282|pages=220–224|pmid=27124458}}</ref> However, contrary to one of LaCour's claims, the identity of the canvasser did not seem to matter; both [[transgender]] and non-transgender canvassers had a similar effect.<ref name="Durably reducing transphobia"/>
== See also == * [[List of scientific misconduct incidents]] * [[Argument from authority]]

(2014, August). [http://static1.squarespace.com/static/53b226f6e4b04c885d525058/t/53ec2c7ee4b0e95a332d8b58/1407986814022/LaCour_2014_Selective_Exposure_Under_Review.pdf The echo chambers are empty: Direct evidence of balanced, not biased, exposure to mass media]. In Annual Meeting of the [[Midwest Political Science Association]]. *{{cite journal | last1 = LaCour | first1 = Michael J. | last2 = Vavreck | first2 = Lynn | year = 2014 | title = Improving media measurement: Evidence from the field|url = https://www.dropbox.com/s/eu38snjb1kfkyyf/LaCour_Vavreck_2014.pdf|format= PDF| journal = [[Political Communication (journal)|Political Communication]] | volume = 31 | issue = | pages = 408–420 | doi = 10.1080/10584609.2014.921258 }}

revision.text:
{{Japanese name|Fujii}} {{nihongo|'''Yoshitaka Fujii'''|藤井 善隆|Fujii Yoshitaka}} is a [[Japanese people|Japanese]] researcher in [[anesthesiology]], who in 2012 was found to have fabricated data in at least 183 [[scientific paper]]s, setting what is believed to be a record for the number of papers by a single author requiring retractions.<ref name=ScienceInsiderNewRecord>{{citation|url=http://news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2012/07/a-new-record-for-retractions-1.html |title=A New Record for Retractions? |first=Dennis |last=Normile |work=Science Insider |publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science |date=2 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120705041049/http://news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2012/07/a-new-record-for-retractions-1.html |archivedate=July 5, 2012 }}</ref>
==Summary of professional career==
Fujii graduated from [[Tokai University]] School of Medicine in 1987 and holds an [[Doctor of Medicine|M.D. degree]].<ref name=PONVprobed>{{cite web| url=http://www.anesthesiologynews.com/ViewArticle.aspx?d=Policy%2B%26%2BManagement&d_id=3&i=March+2012&i_id=820&a_id=20373 | title=Japanese PONV Researcher Probed in Sweeping Research Fraud Case |first=Adam |last=Marcus |date=7 March 2012 |work=Anesthesiology News}}</ref> He attended the Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, [[Tokyo Medical and Dental University]], where he majored in [[anesthesiology]] and received his [[Ph.D.]] in 1991.<ref>Fujii, Yoshitaka (1991) [http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/500000086209?l=enn Diaphragmatic fatigue and its recovery are influenced by cardiac output.] Dissertation, Tokyo Medical and Dental University.</ref> During his career, he worked at institutions including Tokyo Medical and Dental University, the [[University of Tsukuba]], and [[Toho University]].<ref name=ScienceInsiderNewRecord/> According to an online [[Curriculum vitae|CV]], he spent two years in Canada as a research fellow at [[Royal Victoria Hospital, Montreal|Royal Victoria Hospital]], [[McGill University]], before assuming a faculty position at the University of Tsukuba Institute of Clinical Medicine in 1997. He joined the faculty of Toho University in 2005. The main subject of his research publications was [[clinical trial]]s of medications to treat the [[nausea]] and [[vomiting]] that often occurs after [[surgery]].<ref name=PONVprobed/>
In February 2012, after initial investigations into allegations of [[scientific misconduct]], he was dismissed from his position as associate professor of anesthesiology in the Toho University Faculty of Medicine.<ref name=TohoDiscliplinary>{{cite web |url=http://www.toho-u.ac.jp/english/Information/march_6_2012.html |title=Disciplinary Decision concerning Dr. Yoshitaka Fujii |first=Masaru |last=Kuroda |publisher=Toho University Faculty of Medicine |accessdate=3 July 2012}}</ref>
==Research misconduct==
Fujii apparently began publishing falsified data in 1993.<ref name=ScienceInsiderNewRecord/> The first published allegations of research fraud by Fujii appeared in 2000 in a [[letter to the editor]] of the journal {{italics correction|''[[Anesthesia & Analgesia]]''}}<ref name=KrankeApfelNice>{{cite journal |author1=Kranke, P. |author2=Apfel, C.C. |author3=Roewer, N. |author4=Fujii, Y. |title= Reported data on granisetron and postoperative nausea and vomiting by Fujii et al. Are incredibly nice! |url=http://www.anesthesia-analgesia.org/content/90/4/1004.2.full?sid=9b5208d9-42ad-4b40-b428-f0b4f90b28ac | journal=Anesth. Analg. |year=2000 |number= 90 |pages=1004–7}}</ref> by [[Peter Kranke]], [[Christian Apfel]], and others. The letter questioned Fujii's reported findings regarding the effectiveness of [[granisetron]] in controlling post-surgical nausea and vomiting, characterizing the data reported in 47 papers as "incredibly nice" and stating "we became skeptical when we realized that side effects were almost always identical in all groups".<ref name=PONVprobed/><ref name=ToOurReaders>{{cite web |url=http://publicationethics.org/files/u7140/FujiiStatementOfConcern.pdf |title=To our readers |first=Steven L. |last=Shafer |publisher=''Anesthesia & Analgesia'' |date=March 7, 2012}}</ref> A paper published by the same group in 2001 in ''[[Acta Anaesthesiologica Scandinavica]]''<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Kranke, P. |author2=Apfel, C.C. |author3=Eberhart, L.H. |author4=Georgieff, M. |author5=Roewer, N. |title=The influence of a dominating centre on a quantitative systematic review of granisetron for preventing postoperative nausea and vomiting |journal=Acta Anaesthesiol Scand. |year=2001 |volume=45 |pages=659–70}}</ref> reported "consistent discrepancies" between Fujii's data and other researchers' findings on the efficacy of granisetron.<ref name=PONVprobed/><ref name=ToOurReaders/> Fujii dismissed the criticisms of his work, insisting that his results were "true" and asking "How much evidence is required to provide adequate proof?"<ref name=PONVprobed/><ref name=KrankeApfelNice/> Apfel wrote to the [[U.S. Food and Drug Administration]], the Japanese [[Pharmaceuticals and Medical Devices Agency]], and the [[Japanese Society of Anesthesiologists]] to alert them to the possible unreliability of Fujii’s results, but did not receive any response.<ref name=PONVprobed/> No institutional review of Fujii’s research was requested and journals continued to accept new papers submitted by Fujii.<ref name=PONVprobed/><ref name=ToOurReaders/> The editors of ''Anesthesia & Analgesia'' did not follow up on the fraud allegations against Fujii until about 2010, when its editor and the editors of several other journals began a coordinated investigation into the integrity of Fujii's scientific publications after the editor of the journal ''[[Anaesthesia (journal)|Anaesthesia]]'' voiced new concerns.<ref name=PONVprobed/><ref name=ToOurReaders/> In March 2012, the editor of ''Anesthesia & Analgesia'' acknowledged that the journal's response to the allegations made in 2000 had been "inadequate".<ref name=ToOurReaders/>
Two analyses of some of Fujii's publications were released in March 2012. On 7 March, Toho University reported finding that although nine of Fujii's publications were about clinical studies described as having been conducted at [[Ushiku Aiwa General Hospital]], the hospital's [[Institutional review board|ethics committee]] had given Fujii approval for only one study. Following this discovery, eight of the nine papers were retracted for failure to follow established [[medical ethics|ethical standards]] for [[medical research|clinical research]].<ref name=TohoDiscliplinary/> On 8 March, ''Anaesthesia'' published a report by John Carlisle, a consultant anesthetist in the United Kingdom, on his statistical analysis of the data reported in 168 papers by Fujii.<ref name=Carlisle>{{cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2044.2012.07128.x/full |title=The analysis of 168 randomised controlled trials to test data integrity |first=J.B. |last=Carlisle |date=8 March 2012 |journal=Anaesthesia |volume=67 |issue=5 |pages=521–37 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2044.2012.07128.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://the-scientist.com/2012/07/03/anesthesiologist-fabricates-172-papers/ |title=Anesthesiologist Fabricates 172 Papers | first=Jef |last=Akst | date=3 July 2012 |work=[[The Scientist (magazine)|The Scientist]]}}</ref> Carlisle used [[statistical methods]] to evaluate whether the published distributions of various variables were consistent with the distributions that could be expected to result from random chance. He found that many of the data sets were "extremely unlikely to have arisen by chance", noting that many of the distributions had "likelihoods that are infinitesimally small", citing a calculated probability of 6.78 × 10<sup>−9</sup>, or about 1 in 150 million. Accordingly, he recommended that data published by Fujii should be "excluded from meta-analyses or reviews" until such time that the unlikely results could be satisfactorily explained.<ref name=Carlisle/>
In April, the editors of 23 scientific journals made a public request for an investigation of Fujii's research by the seven Japanese institutions named as affiliations in his published papers.<ref name=ScienceInsiderNewRecord/> A committee of the Japanese Society of Anesthesiologists, headed by [[Koji Sumikawa]] of [[Nagasaki University]], undertook an examination of 212 of the 249 papers credited to Fujii. The committee interviewed Fujii's listed co-authors and other people who had been involved with Fujii's research. Committee members also attempted to obtain and review [[laboratory notebook]]s, patient records, and other raw data from his studies.<ref name=ScienceInsiderNewRecord/> On 29 June 2012, the committee reported finding that a total of 172 papers contained fabricated data. Of these, 126 papers were determined to have been "totally fabricated". The report stated: "It is as if someone sat at a desk and wrote a novel about a research idea." The committee found that three of the 212 papers were valid. For 37 of the 212 papers, the committee was unable to determine whether data had been fabricated.<ref name=ScienceInsiderNewRecord/>
The investigators observed that Fujii seemed to have been deliberately ambiguous about details such as the dates of the studies and the names of the institutions where they were conducted, apparently to reduce the possibility that his fraud would be detected. Also, by listing co-authors from institutions other than his current employer, he conveyed the impression that the papers described studies done at multiple hospitals.<ref name=MarcusAnesNewsJuly/> Several scientists listed as co-authors were not aware that Fujii had included their names on his papers; two named co-authors said that their signatures had been [[forgery|forged]] on a cover letter submitting the paper to the journal.<ref name=ScienceInsiderNewRecord/><ref name=MarcusAnesNewsJuly/> [[Retraction Watch]] suggested that the supposed co-authors might not have been aware that their names had been misused because the papers had received few citations.<ref name=ScienceInsiderNewRecord/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://retractionwatch.wordpress.com/2012/06/18/three-more-fujii-papers-fall-for-lack-of-irb-approval/ |title=Three more Fujii papers fall for lack of IRB approval |publisher=Retraction Watch |date=18 June 2012}}</ref> Investigators found that one of Fujii's co-authors, [[Hidenori Toyooka]], who collaborated with Fujii on "dozens" of papers, may have been aware of the deception.<ref name=MarcusAnesNewsJuly>{{cite web |url=http://www.anesthesiologynews.com/ViewArticle.aspx?d=Web%2BExclusives&d_id=175&i=June+2012&i_id=854&a_id=21194 |title=Report: Japanese Anesthesiologist Fabricated Data in 172 Studies; Inquiry into PONV researcher Yoshitaka Fujii, MD, finds only three of 212 papers free of fraud |first=Adam |last=Marcus |date=July 2, 2012 |work=Anesthesiology News}}</ref>
==Previous record for retractions==
The researcher believed to have previously held the record for the most retractions of scientific papers by a single author was another anesthesiologist, [[Joachim Boldt]] of Germany, author of about 90 papers that required retractions.<ref name=ScienceInsiderNewRecord/>
== See also == * [[List of scientific misconduct incidents]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.bjs.co.uk/SpringboardWebApp/userfiles/bjsurg/file/Fujii_Joint_Editorial_Request_Regarding_Dr_Yoshitaka_Fujii.pdf Joint Editors-in-Chief Request for Determination Regarding Papers Published by Dr. Yoshitaka Fujii], 9 April 2012 * Koji Sumikawa, M.D. (Vice President, Japanese Society of Anesthesiologists and Chief, Special Investigation Committee on Papers by Fujii), [http://www.anesth.or.jp/english/pdf/news20120629.pdf The Results of Investigation into Dr.Yoshitaka Fujii’s papers], Japanese Society of Anesthesiologists, 29 June 2012
